output: I'm going to do it.

Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms de Sarnec, on her excellent synthesis work, even in a context in which the Commission and, above all, the Council have not always shown great openness towards the cases of this Parliament.
The Committee on Development approved my report unanimously, some of our concerns were welcomed, and we are still rather dissatisfied on other points.

However, we are taking a step back in a spirit of responsibility, considering it essential to approve the whole package at first reading, which will ensure that it is ready for the beginning of the journey on 1 January.
It is great to have quadrupled the funds for students, but beware, a significant proportion comes from the resources allocated to development, DCI and Cotonou.
We will therefore be difficult to demand full compliance with the overall regulatory framework, in particular with regard to the DCI.

For now, I send a sincere word of encouragement to the many European boys from all over the world who, with a spirit of friendship, sharing, wanting to learn and grow, will be the protagonists of this extraordinary event.
-Good morning. -Congratulations to the speaker.
As a member of the Committee on Petitions, I would like to thank and invite you on the basis of the data in the report and also on the basis of my personal experience.

I would like to thank you for the progress made compared to the previous year, when we went from 449 to 518 admissible cases, from 12 to 16 of the total, with an increase in the number of investigations carried out.
I think the road ahead is therefore a good one.
However, and here comes the invitation, efforts in terms of communication must be further increased.
Let us study together effective ways, perhaps starting from our schools, to ensure that citizens have quality information about the figure, role and competences of the European Ombudsman.
There are interesting projects in this regard that have started this year that need to be implemented and supported.
In this way, today's already good numbers will certainly continue to improve.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our primary objective is to ensure that Europe has a common agricultural policy after 2013.

We believe that this is fundamental not only to protect the agricultural sector and the socioeconomic fabric in the Member States, but also because, at the dawn of the third millennium, it is strategically necessary to ensure Europe's security of food supply.

We want to emphasize that we must continue to implement policies to support the individual SMEs where this is necessary, and in particular we believe that in the tobacco sector the decoupling of aid should provide for the possibility of a reduction in the number of SMEs.

We need to maintain partial coupled aid until 2013, in order to avoid total abandonment of production, because this would jeopardise entire sectors, creating unemployment and various economic and environmental problems in particularly disadvantaged areas.
I would remind the Commissioner and the President that the European Parliament has already expressed itself in favour of this subject by a large majority.

In order to rebalance the market in the short term and to allow a soft exit from the long-term quota system, it would be appropriate to increase the quota by 2 from each marketing campaign from 2009 to 2014.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to see the proof of the Commission's work as very positive.
The co-decision on agriculture was taken through the strengthened cooperation between the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament.
It is a good omen and it will also allow me to congratulate Mr Capolas Santos, of course, on his balanced report.
report on modulation, on young farmers, on job security, as well as on the new challenges.
We are in a difficult transition, we know about the approach and the decoupling, other innovative measures.
We must take advantage of this step to initiate a serious reflection on the future of the tobacco industry, which is a very important sector in the European Union.
After 2013, to update the objectives and new missions of the CAP and to begin to discuss a breakthrough of the dichotomy between the first and second pillars.

Mr President, I appreciate the great efforts of our rapporteur, Mr Capolas Santos, to keep the CAP closer to European farmers and citizens rather than to market needs and to reconcile the different concerns in the face of the many challenges at stake.
A common approach by the 27 Member States in this area is therefore essential, but it is important to maintain the instruments for supporting and managing the markets for the main productions.

I am thinking, for example, of the domestic sector or tobacco aid, the abolition of which would certainly not contribute to the reduction of tobacco but rather to the elimination of an important European production and the social fabric associated with it.
However, such instruments must always take account of the extremely varied reality of the European landscape.
The milk quota system currently in force, for example, meets outdated criteria.
The increase of 1 proposed by the compromise is not sufficient to meet the internal demand of most Member States.

A more flexible system is therefore needed, which offers each Member State the possibility of responding to its own needs, which would also favour the European competitiveness of the sector on the international market.
Mr President, our group is quite satisfied with these two proposals.
I am quite satisfied with a defect in ambition, and we think that we could have done better and more.

There are signs of openness, of civility, which are immediately followed, even sometimes in the debate, within this Parliament, by signs of rigidity, especially from the Council, of great and strong protectionism.

This also applies to the blue card, there is a resistance to some central principles, equal work, equal pay, which is a sacrosanct and natural principle, but we have also found some points of harshness on this.

We believe that it is essential to overcome the principle of Community preference, to overcome the idea that there is a Europe travelling at two speeds, which is why the principle of Community preference must prevail.
We believe that the call to the labour market is important, but the labour market cannot be the only regulatory principle.
There are other inclusive principles of political and social civilization that must be part of immigration policies.
Legal immigration means equal dignity and opportunity, or let's go back to selective, partial, discriminatory immigration.
We'd like to avoid it.

That is why, on behalf of the Group, I support Mr Moreno's proposal to the Commission to try to think of a blue card which is not only linked to that 3 highly qualified immigrants, but which seeks to find legal and concrete tools to open up the immigration market.
Immigration must be inclusion, if it becomes a choice it is no longer a positive policy.

Madam President, in the face of the very serious crisis that is investing the automotive sector from America to our continent, Europe is faced with a very clear dilemma: either remain inert and observe this collapse in demand and demand for European cars.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter.
We are strongly in favour of this second option and we ask the Commission and the Council for decision and determination.
We have appreciated the words of Commissioner Verheugen and we hope that some colleagues will not be too slow to show this determination.
It is an exceptional situation, so exceptional must also be the answers.

Moreover, ladies and gentlemen, the financial crisis has shown us some interventions by political and economic authorities who have made choices of behaviour, investment in public resources which, until a few months ago, were unthinkable.

But our intervention, and I conclude, must be selective: reconcile the strategy with the emergency, support, both through the eased credits and the support for demand, a selective orientation towards more environmentally sustainable productions.
Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, unfortunately the terrorist events that have occurred since 2001 have not been reported.

The various conflicts in India these days, present in many parts of the world, make this issue, the issue of the arms trade, of particular importance for the present and the future in the broadest sense.
Too often, praiseworthy intentions expressed at the level of declarations of principles are not then put into practice.

It is clear to everyone that the issue is delicate, involves important industrial and commercial processes and therefore the difficulty of ratifying a system of control and regulation by all Member States, especially the Member States, is understandable.
However, the rise of events and the awareness that the internal and external trafficking of arms is illegal, pushes for the urgency of legally regulating this sector effectively.
The ongoing directive on the transfer of defence-related goods within the Community will also have real meaning if the Code of Conduct is quickly ratified.

I am sorry that the President-in-Office of the Council has left, but after what he said, and I therefore neglect some other aspects of what I had prepared, after what he said, everything seems to be in place.
In reality, it doesn't seem that way at all.
So I believe that the commitment that the Minister has made here tonight, as well as many other commitments made by many others in other circumstances, can be fulfilled.

I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is prepared to accept the amendments tabled by the Committee on the Rules of Procedure, the Verification of Credentials and Immunities.
It would be commendable if France did so, in addition to declaring it here in the House and then perhaps not having concrete results.
Mr President, I think that in these days we should become more aware that when we talk about Tibet and the Dalai Lama, we are talking about ourselves above all.
A few days ago, to the simple announcement that the European President, that President Sarkozy dared to
In Poland, meeting the Dalai Lama, we were treated without even giving us eight days, dismissed, no meeting.
The great Europe allows itself to welcome or to speak, to accept and to listen to the Dalai Lama, because this is the
I think it is clear that we know that if the European people were called as the European people, 80 would be in favour of the Dalai Lama.
I'm going to do it.
It is argued that the 2020 European Directive imposes too high costs on the European Union's economy.
Among these is the Italian Government, which has presented estimates of almost double costs, without convincing evidence.

However, such positions underestimate the future price of fossil fuels and ignore the enormous benefits of the rapid spread of renewable energy, such as the security of supply, but above all the creation of new jobs in a time of recession when thousands of workers are being driven out of production processes.
Increased energy efficiency and widespread use of renewable sources are the recipe for getting out of the economic crisis.
Concentrating a large part of public funds to save the banks means re-proposing the same economic model, all based on finance, that created the crisis that we are trying to combat.
The economic situation cannot be addressed without changes in strategy.
The EU directive is aimed at innovation and, above all, at tackling in time the upheavals created by the climate change that is now taking place.
A problem which will weigh increasingly heavily on the lives of European citizens and on the economies of the Member States.
That is why public investment must not once again go to support traditional sectors, but must focus on activities that bring innovation in the energy and environmental fields.
Key factors for the growth of the renewable energy sector are the development of distribution networks and priority access to these networks.
Between the 1960s and 1980s, the enormous expenditure on network infrastructure, on large centralised systems, was supported by large public investments.
This aspect must also be applied to ensure the future of the renewable energy system.
It is therefore necessary to manage renewable energy generation plants with new technologies, which is why investment, research and technology development are needed.
There remains the urgency of approving this package at first reading in the December plenary, as European citizens expect.
We cannot allow the short-sightedness of the interests of some States and some economic interests to block this process.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in future memory, if the future has a memory, we are witnessing a genetic change in that Parliament, in that European Union, Mr President, which is not a memory.
In 1985, you knew and helped to bring the European Fatherland to life against the disastrous illusion of Europe, the old Europe of the Fatherlands.
Today we are going in that direction every day.
Yesterday and the day before yesterday, at the Council, Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals was recalled in depth, an old nationalist and non-Europeanist memory.
The Europe of Cadenault Calargi, but of Winston Churchill, of our names that give our Parliament its name.
Today we are only talking about partnership to all those who want to be members, to be in Europe, and I think we are talking about them.
I am handing over the Mediterranean to a most dangerous fate, and I am certainly hurting the Europeanists and the democrats of those countries.

The Council's proposal, which transcends the good balance found in its time, I think of the great work done in this respect by Mr Luigi Coccilovo, does not find our support, because it marks an objective backwardness on the part of the European Union.
It is a choice that weakens the rights of workers, which are then the rights of all of us, of our children, of normal people.
And I don't want this speech to be exchanged as a union or a corporation speech, because I'm defending health care workers.
No, it's not like that. As a politician, I don't act on behalf of corporations or unions, I act on behalf of the citizens.
I think of them when I choose, I think of their social rights, which are fundamental to me in Europe.

I do not think it is a good Europe, one that does not move forward while the world moves forward, but rather makes glaring errors of perspective, exchanging the weakening of protections for flexibility and freedom.
This is all the more serious at a time when Europe is experiencing its worst crisis and sees no prospects for prosperity or growth.

If we do not understand, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, representatives of the Council and the Commission, if we do not understand that at the moment millions of workers are at risk of losing their jobs and feel in a state of weakness and precariousness.

And they certainly do not have the voluntary contractual capacity, other than opt-out, so I have to say that we have no knowledge of what is really happening in the social and family life of Europeans.
That is why we will support the proposals of the rapporteur, Mr Sergas, and we hope that the whole of Parliament will do so.
I must say that the Council's unwillingness to negotiate at this stage forces us to win a seat for conciliation, a seat for comparison and negotiation.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with an important compromise for Europe, even though the European Parliament has had to swallow some scraps.
In this respect, the text on renewables, which emerged from the trilogue, contains a clear definition of the objectives and, above all, of the mandatory nature of the objectives themselves.
The 2014 revision clause is key to greater flexibility to focus on the reduction target of 20 if conditions are in place to push it up to 30 by 2020.

It should be stressed that the most powerful and economically advantageous flexibility instrument for the Member States is national efficiency measures in the construction, transport and industrial sectors and the best use of electricity.
The 10 mandatory target for biofuels should be qualified with requirements for efficiency in processing processes, by adopting environmental and social sustainability criteria.
The use of biomass should be directed towards non-controversial areas and towards more effective conversion technologies than first- and second-generation biofuels.
The agreement reached by the Council and the will of the European Parliament send a positive message that the very serious economic crisis cannot be tackled without changes in strategy.
Who, like Berlusconi, took advantage of the European directive of the three twenties by calling it a Don Quixote plan, has been defeated.

The package which this Parliament is called upon to approve, despite the watering down due to the selfishness of the Member States, is aimed at providing innovative responses to mitigate the impact of climate change.
If we do not act quickly, this problem will weigh more heavily on the European economy, but above all on the lives of European citizens.
Mr President, Commissioner, I am very grateful, first of all, to the President of the European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture, Mr Parrish, for his excellent report.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter.
It is undeniable that Mediterranean food is part of the historical and cultural heritage of our continent, as is its health principle.
The Commission itself, in the White Paper on obesity, has identified it as an absolutely adequate natural medicine.
The health benefits are scientifically proven and enjoy a wide fortune abroad, starting with the United States.
And so it happens that the concept expands to denature its originality.
That is why the recognition by UNESCO establishes a definition to protect this peculiarity, and I want to say to Mr Parrish that
Because of the peculiarity of European gastronomic culture today, we speak of Mediterranean food, but certainly not as the only peculiarity of European gastronomic wealth.
Commissioner, you have maintained your predecessor's commitment to recognise the importance of this initiative, and for that I thank you.
You have stressed that you have no decision-making power within the framework of the UNESCO procedure, but I think you will be able to make a statement.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are starting from a concept, the Mediterranean diet, as confirmed by numerous studies, promotes the fight against obesity and cardiovascular disease and is generally very positive for human health in many respects.

But here the point is not to claim to impose the Mediterranean diet throughout the EU or to try to favour it over other food regimes which are better suited to different climates and regions of the Mediterranean.
But we have a duty to protect it, to define it in its contents and in its characteristics, to defend it from imitations and external contaminations that could damage its image and value.
It must therefore be valued, like all other European cultural expressions, which deserve to be defended and promoted globally.
It is a model that the world is trying to copy, so it is important to specify its peculiarities and safeguard it to prevent a completely European heritage from being lost in the sea of globalisation.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the work of Mrs Lampedusa, a work in which I share a great deal.
On the other hand, I am, however, puzzled by some aspects, perhaps due to excessive confidence in the Commission's assessments.
First of all, I think that the expected growth in gas demand is reductive.
If so, I fear a negative impact on the sources of funding for the projects.
As regards infrastructure, the relevant projects have different stages of maturation.

Instead of redefining their priorities in an abstract way, with a serious shortage for the Mediterranean area, it is appropriate to re-evaluate them for development times, financial structure, available supplies and the relationship between public support and private commitment.
The honourable Member also recommended a diversification of sources and routes of approach.
One example is the Southern Corridor.
On such issues, however, I believe that a programmatic approach divided into phases is necessary.

In fact, if Caspian gas is available in the first phase, only Azerbaijani gas will be available, access to other countries will be registered in the second phase, but making the market more complex for political, regulatory and infrastructure reasons.
The Commission's proposal for a Caspian Development Cooperation can start with such issues if it is intended, among other things, to facilitate the development of the missing infrastructure.
What is the penultimate aspect? There is no doubt that solidarity mechanisms are fundamental to the Union's energy policies, including in relation to the Treaty of Lisbon.
However, it is appropriate that the feasibility of such measures should avoid, in addition to possible distortions, excessively burdensome processes.

Finally, external relations and any important objectives, in addition to the role of the Energy Charter, the expansion of energy commitments, in particular to transit countries, also in the field of renewable energy.
I'm going to do it.

Madam President, the crisis in the car sector has become a crisis of an entire sector, of the inducement of other connected sectors, of commercial networks and therefore of services, and from dramatic prospects in the field of employment.

I think that even the dramatic decline in enrolment in recent months, which is said to be less than 33 for some Member States this month, less than 20 etc., shows that it is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector, nor is it born within the sector or within this or that company because of managerial errors.
It is a systemic crisis and as such it must be urgently and decisively addressed by the European institutions themselves.
Some remedies seem to have been identified, but it is important how to achieve them, with what resources and with what prospects for innovation.
It is certainly necessary to support the demand that consumption is the only driver of recovery.

But while this response to supporting consumption is being made, which is a medium-term response, I think we must say that we need credit support immediately to resume production, pay for materials, support employment, even in the face of a decline in demand and demand.
So the credit scope, but we said it's important how.
I too call for a stronger role for Europe here. It is important that the European institutions give a signal.

America is intervening, some European countries are intervening, and I too hope that my country will move from generic proposals to concrete initiatives, but I hope that there will be stronger European action in the recovery plan and also beyond the recovery plan.

Because I think, and our Commissioner has said it in a few verses, that the fate of the big European houses is a common fate and the big European producers must not find competition within the European market.
But they must find a strong, decisive and coordinated European response, because the fate of the European car market is measured in the ability to face global competition together.

There is the other point which has been recalled, as Sacconis said, and I will repeat it, support is not a help, or worse, a relief, which leaves everything as it is, but an incentive for a competitive capacity.
the future of the sector in the context of innovation, environmentally friendly production and also more environmentally friendly technologies and the safety of passengers and transport.
We are satisfied with Belarus' new willingness to cooperate with the European Union and the international community.
We are very cautious with Lukashenko, but welcome to a new course in this area.
We will not tire of stressing the need for a comprehensive and substantial change of course in the context of respect for human rights.

On one point, I think that the Commission could demand clearer and more linear behaviour from Minsk, and I am referring to the situation of children, tens of thousands of guests for a few months in European families.
For several years, the Belarusian government has had absurd, sometimes incomprehensible, attitudes, often cancelling the stays of minors at the last minute, mortifying the families of minors.
It is a great way to show hospitality and to give a new sound of applause to children who, often orphans and coming from very complicated family situations, have suffered completely.
On the other hand, we are trying to reach a change of course as soon as possible.
Mr President, reading the text of this document gives the impression that those who wrote it do not want an improvement but a deterioration in relations between the European Union and Russia.
If this is the objective of Europe, then this document is excellent, if it is not, then it is bad.
I think it's a terrible document.
How can we think of a future of new tensions with a country whose indispensability we recognize in our own interest?
In the next 40 years, we will have to rely on the traditional energy resources that Russia is rich in.
I'm not going to lie to you.
Secondly, the way and the tones in these pages Europe speaks an imperial language, not the language of those who respect their interlocutor.

This is contrary to our own policy of good neighbourliness and it would not be right to use it even against a small country, less than ever against a large country which rightly demands to be respected.

It is a matter of realism first of all the European Parliament is about to approve I fear a document written in the spirit of the cold war old, useless, harmful, counterproductive, just at the time when the new American president comes to enter into a new dialogue with Moscow.
With this approach, Europe cannot claim any leadership and I hope that the Commission will not accept these recommendations.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I appreciate the rapporteur's proposal, but this resolution makes too much reference not only to this point, but also to this note of the proposed oral amendment.

But in so many other parts of the resolution you refer to all the Member States for different reasons and you also refer to the same subject which you ask to be deleted from the note for the same subjects to other parts of the resolution.

So, Mr President, I think it would be appropriate for the honourable Member, and I am proposing this, to ask for the resolution to be amended further and therefore to return to the committee so that it can be reviewed.
I would like to ask the Commissioner what he thinks of what has happened within the Fiat here in Brussels.
Fiat has become a seizure that has never been of its leaders by the workers with the sole purpose of decapitating the union.
There was no kidnapping on April 9th or May.
The news was spread by Fiat in an attempt to discredit workers who defend their future against 24 layoffs.
Fiat refuses to have any meetings and any discussions and any negotiations with the trade union representatives.
The only objective is to dismiss 24 workers, 12 of whom are trade union representatives.
I think it would be appropriate for Parliament to discuss not only this but also the anti-union and non-respectful behaviour of the workers' rights of Fiat and its subsidiaries.

There are many large European multinationals which then take advantage of the rules, sometimes also of subsidies from the national states and the European Union, and which do not respect the rights of workers.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Czech Presidency, the Commission, the President of the Committee on Energy and Industry, Mr Nybler, and my colleagues from the other side of the House.
I would like to thank the rapporteurs of this energy package, the shadow rapporteurs, the secretariat of the Commission and all its officials for the cooperation and competence shown in this dossier.
We can and must all be proud of the result achieved, and I am, thinking of the effort made when I inherited the directive on the internal gas market, with problems that are not easy to solve.

I am pleased to have made this second experience of being a Member of the European Parliament coincide with the final phase of this package, which I consider to be one of the most important files of this legislature in favour of the citizens of Europe, our voters.
The Gas Directive, which will enter into force from 2011, brings significant innovations in the sector.
It is an ITO that guarantees the opening up of markets and a real progress towards a system that really allows the European Union to speak with one voice on energy.
The ILO is the real novelty of this package and it is the one on which it can be said that the European Parliament has had the best result.
The new gas directive gives great importance to the gas authorities and the agency.
This directive legitimizes the authorities in their role, in particular in those countries where they have to start ex novo activity.

It is therefore of the utmost importance to have outlined the role and competences of these bodies and to have given them broad powers, since it is the responsibility of the authorities to control the common energy market.
Another tax that has been introduced in the trilogue phase is the exemption from the common rules of the so-called closed systems, i.e. airports, hospitals, stations, industrial sites, etc.
They are subject to a more favourable regime, and this is a demonstration of the attention that the new directive pays to the needs of the European citizen.

It is the European citizen, in my view, who will really benefit from this directive, because by using smart meters he will have access to all the information on the ballot and will be able to assess the best offer on the market and choose his supplier.

It is true that it will take years to see the effects of this liberalisation, but it is undeniable that the entry of new operators into the market will lead to a reduction in prices and market conditions more favourable to the citizens of the Union.
Another important element is the recognition of European transmission network systems, which will ensure the security of gas supply to European citizens.
All this also goes through the strengthening and creation of new infrastructures, such as gasifiers and storage sites, which will be the engine of the third package.
It therefore requires the opening up of a competitive market that guarantees long-term investment and contracts by companies in the sector.
In particular, in the new Member States, where the creation of new infrastructure would also make it possible to solve problems of centuries-old dependence.
The protection of the weakest consumer was taken into account, giving the national and regional authorities the possibility of guaranteeing the supply of gas at the most critical moments.
The successful outcome of the gas directive and of the entire energy package once again highlights the role of Europe and its institutions for European citizens.

Once again we are in this House to defend a food, cultural and rural heritage that comes from an ancient tradition, an invaluable heritage that the world envies us for, which represents an enormous wealth for the economy and also for the identity of our Union.
A heritage which today risks being in serious difficulty because of the will of the Commission and the Council to abolish the coupage ban on the production of ros wines.
It will find its ratification without the intervention of Parliament, the body which officially represents the millions of citizens, producers and consumers, who will be affected by this initiative.

The Commission proposes to allow the production of red wines simply by mixing red and white wines, as countries that do not possess our skills and professionalism do, under the simple pretext of responding to international competition.

As a confirmation of the question, I would like to emphasize that the lowering of the quality of our productions is the result of centuries of tradition and research, of very important investments, of passion.
And care for detail is not the answer we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this, when the average consumer is certainly more concerned with price than with a label.

To counterbalance this decision, it would be enough to find a name for the new product and inform consumers of the existence of two different types of ros, the different quality of the products, the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of industry professionals.
Who's gonna pay for all this?

Does the Commission envisage any support programme in this respect, or will the producers still have to pay after having asked them to fight unfairly against low-cost competition in already very difficult times?
I hope that the Commission and the Council will know how to make the right choice and, if necessary, revise this procedure completely.
Mr President, first of all let me greet the President of the DTP party, Mr Ahmet Trk, who is here with us in the podium and who is following the debate.
Dear Ahmed, know that we are in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle that your party is waging in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognise the DTP as an indispensable instrument for the promotion of democracy in Turkey and therefore strongly condemn the police operations carried out by the DTP.
Prime Minister Erdogan has ordered the imprisonment of all three DTP vice presidents, along with over 300 militants and sympathizers.
The victory of the DTP in the last administrative elections shows that the DTP party is a party with strong popular and democratic support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has asked Prime Minister Erdogan to have direct discussions with the DTP, and instead his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, more prisons.
Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have so far supported Turkey's accession process to the European Union, while supporting the reform process in that country.

But I believe that in the last two years, and especially in the last few months, Erdogan has shown another face, that of a leader compromised with the worst part of the Turkish army, who simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, the prisons are filled with Kurds, it is Erdogan himself who is closing any prospect of Turkey's accession.
It is his responsibility, and his alone, for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and for the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either he makes the search for a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish issue a priority that passes, let it be clear, through direct negotiations with the WTO, or we will be calling for the suspension of negotiations on accession to the European Union.

The path of Turkey's accession to the Union passes through Diyarbakir and the DTP, otherwise we, those who have supported the accession process so far, will be calling for a pause in reflection which may be final.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Council for sharing the principles and, above all, if I may, Commissioner Barrot, with whom I had a very productive exchange of views, which was very useful to me in the work we then carried out in the House.

I would also like to thank from the bottom of my heart the colleagues who have worked on this report, giving me ideas and clearly bringing all their experience, firstly Mr Demetrio, Baroness Ludford and the excellent President Depr.

I would like to say that exactly what both Demetriou and Lafourche de Pr are saying is the most important thing, the challenge of the European Union, because to achieve a united European judicial culture
Of course, fighting a serious battle over what Depr says, the independence of the judiciary, the guarantees and eradicating the disparities of the various judicial systems are the challenges we face.
But I think the work we've done allows us to be optimistic.
I would like to say to Mr Romagnoli that I say it from my point of view, which should also be his, that there is certainly a pessimism for Italy about reason, but we must have a

I am optimistic about the will and the work that you, Mr Romagnoli, have also done and the contribution you have made to the report means that we can all together build the European Union, and the European Union is also a reality for us Italians.

It seems that the thousands of deaths that have occurred so far from asbestos, the tens of thousands of deaths that have occurred in the past few years, are not the same as the deaths that have occurred in the past.
We know that the waiting time can be as long as 15 years and even 20 years, and they don't count for anything.
It seems that the Eternity trial that began in Turin, about what happened in Casale Monferrato, where there is no family that has not had a mourning inside, does not continue.
The amending directive should have been operationally banned by the Member States by applying the directive in 1999.
States should have taken all possible precautions to protect exposed workers by applying the 2003 directive, closing factories, repairing contaminated sites, compensating victims and populations.
This hasn't happened all the time.
Little or nothing has been done.
I have already spoken of the Turin trial, where Swiss and Belgian masters are accused.
Everyone knew that little had been done and that it was above all industry that was evading its responsibilities, acting between the lines of inertia and public authorities.
Examples of inertia are what is happening, for example, in Italy, in Brioni, where the asbestos has not been removed, in Porto Marghera, in Cengio, where the dead are still being counted.
Today, industry is asking the Commission to tolerate yet another derogation, already granted for a limited time under the 2006 RIC Regulation, for chrysotile asbestos fibres.

It is true that low-voltage electrolysis plants have a limited application and only in a few plants, but where industrialists claim the impossibility of any alternative, the closure of the plants is painful.

But alternatives to this process have been found in Sweden, using technologies in the replacement of non-mianto membranes for low voltage, and a similar solution has also been adopted for the production of hydrogen.
Because in some states, yes and in others, no?
Because, as in the long battle for the ban on PCBs, there have been countless omissions and reluctance to move, even backed up by the European Commission's DG Enterprise.
Even in this case, the right example was not given.
The 1999 directive on the prohibition of asbestos required that the revision of such authorisation be preceded by an opinion of the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, which was never produced.
Is this how the Commission respects the directives?
Not to mention the union, which says it hasn't even been consulted.
The European Parliament makes its own efforts to appeal to the fullness of others.

This resolution calls on the Commission to fill a legislative gap on the ban on second-hand products containing asbestos, roofing, air conditioning and other items by 2009 and to remove them permanently.
If precise dates are set, once again, for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but the targets were already written in 1999.
Ten years have passed and he continues to die.
The GUE NGL had called, among the first initiatives of this legislature, for the establishment of a Community fund for compensation to victims, of ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the Commission, which today, instead, is flattening behind the will of the multinationals.
Instead, it is necessary to move to concrete commitments.
Only when these are based on the same requirements of this resolution will we be able to be comprehensive.
Today this will is not shown, which is why we are voting against the granting of the derogation.
Mr President, I wanted to convey to President Buzek the pride I feel at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament, which is chaired by you.
I believe that the sacrifices of the last 20 years, which she made in her country and which today represent those 12 countries of which we spoke earlier in this session, give strength to Europe.
But I also want to convey my concern to you by listening to your programme, to the content of your speech, which I hope will give strength to this Parliament.
I hope that what has been announced will come true.

I hope that the next President of the European Commission, surely President Barroso, will want to listen to her for the strong words she has spoken, to make sure that this Parliament gives the answers to more than

The 550 million citizens who in this Europe have voted for us, wanted us and want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that perhaps Europe has certainly tried to give but has not completely succeeded in giving.
On this activity of hers, I express my hopes and I am sure that with her we will be able to reach the certainties that she herself has given us.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is not my intention, much less that of my group, which supported and wanted this debate, to transfer to the European level the attributes of Italian internal policy.

The question of freedom of information concerns all of us, it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at Community level in order to counter political and economic conditions and to ensure real pluralism of information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, consists precisely in the existence of a dangerous interweaving between media, political and economic powers.

That is why we are calling for a European regulatory intervention, an intervention which, far from being an act of anti-Italianism, serves to protect information pluralism by avoiding concentration and conflict of interest.

That is why today we are asking the Commission to act as soon as possible, as this Parliament has asked in the past, to provide the European Union with common rules to protect freedom of information for all European citizens.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am aware that on 30 September last the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008 a report was voted on, by rapporteur Marianne Micko, which called on the European Commission and the Member States to protect, I quote, the multiplicity of
to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee equal access to free and diversified media for all citizens of the European Union.

Even earlier, in 2004, a report by rapporteur Bogert Kvack on the risks of violation of freedom of expression and information in the European Union was voted in Parliament, calling on the Commission to present a communication on guaranteeing media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet given clear answers to Parliament's requests.

You will note, Commissioner, that I have not appointed my country or my President of the Council, but in this seat as a European citizen I ask you what the Commission intends to do at European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all the Member States.
Mr President, I have seen the speech on the vote held yesterday in the Committee on the Environment repeated many times.
I would like it to be clear, however, that not everything can be reduced to a single extremist ideological position.

We have heard so many of our colleagues' positions which are very varied, much more articulate, much more common sense and therefore, being more true to reality, I think more able to provide real answers.
When this mistake was made of identifying a problem in such an ideological way, no answers were given, but they were made.
And Europe in this should be masterful in not repeating the same mistakes, even with different clothes and labels that seem to be much more friendly.
I must remind you that the Emissions Trading Directive itself provides that the virtuous path of the European Union is to be assessed by the Commission on the basis of the outcome of the conference.
We must go to the conference with strong positions, with clear ideas, but with an absolute desire to divide the people equally.

I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report, and I would also like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report, and I would also like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report.

But we cannot help but make a distinction between developing countries, there are developing countries, really, there are countries whose economies have now emerged, I am talking about India, China, Brazil.

These are fundamental points, we want the Kyoto Protocol itself to maintain its environmental significance and, above all, we want to avoid creating a financial bubble at the expense of our European companies.
It is very important for two reasons: firstly, the topic of research on the fight against neurodegenerative diseases and, secondly, the way in which joint programming is carried out in research.
We would obviously have preferred, and it has been said and is the subject of our question, a more direct participation of Parliament in the pilot project.

If we do not have to stop now and we have to move forward, we ask for guarantees that our opinion will be taken into account in the reception of the Competitiveness Council and that a more certain legal basis will be clarified for the future, for Parliament's full involvement and for a more full ownership in this area of research.

Now we must intervene with adequate means and resources to prevent and eradicate such a widespread plague as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and other diseases that are destined to grow in the face of population ageing.
We call for a focus on large-scale, large-scale studies, both diagnostic and treatment identification.

Research on biomarkers, on early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the creation of vast databases, the search for curative medicines and appropriate treatment models and services seem to be fundamental.

I feel that there is only one request to be made in this House: neither the subjectivity of patients, which is too often excluded in this type of disease, nor the involvement of associations of patients and relatives should be neglected.
From a methodological point of view, we consider joint research projects to be very important because they meet a fundamental need, that of concentrating efforts and resources.
We need to overcome these fragmentations, these duplications, and thus be able to make a critical mass sufficient to give adequate results to this type of research.

If we think that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts are investing tens of millions of euros, we realize how much remains to be done and how much we must do by converging on projects

We are talking about shared strategies, shared programmes between the States and Europe, and common programmes between public and private actors, without neglecting the international framework that puts us in contact with the great scientific realities at international level.
What are the novelties of the Stockholm programme compared to the Hague programme, a fair balance between rights and security and legal protection in both criminal and civil matters?
Security is a right not to be assaulted in the workplace, to walk the streets without risking your life, not to be subjected to violence as women, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
States and Europe must guarantee security.
But an act of security that undermines the guarantees of freedom is an act that denies certainty to the law and is therefore a source of insecurity and barbarism.
Guantanamo Bay.
Europe is the home of rights.
The Stockholm Programme defines them with a certain amount of detail.

Today, a fair balance between the discipline of anti-criminal repression on the one hand and the daily life of citizens, their family, social, economic, work, study relationships, all regulated by civil law and civil justice.
This is the Europe of the citizen.
It must be built within the States and in the Community institutions.
European society is more united, with more intense mobility than you might think.
Mobility is now a right.
Conflicts between states are not impermeable walls, they are networks through which society filters every day.
Stockholm is the institutional framework for judicial cooperation, mutual recognition, European justice, national justice.
It is a European right, national and Community, a European citizen, a European judge, national and Community.

European rules are dictated by Community rules and the jurisprudence of the European courts, but they also come from the behaviour of workers, businesses, students, magistrates, even national ones, of European networks among justice operators.
So bottom up, and this process from below, the Stockholm programme wants to support.
Parliament has made a great effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, unified vote, on which we have worked intensively.
The Council shall respectfully take this into account.
Lisbon is not yet in operation, but it is there, well present.
Let the Council be ambitious, Mr Minister, and treasure what we have worked out here and the wealth of incentives that comes out of it.
I must say that the Commission has done a very important job, the rapporteur has done a very good job, and I must also say that there has been political compactness.

This is because from the outset we wanted to send a very clear message that we intend to work very hard to ensure transparency, correctness and legality in the management of public funds and therefore in the verification of budgets.
There have been very significant steps forward with the Council, which at first did not want to respond.
I personally acknowledge this to the Swedish Presidency, which has always wanted to demonstrate that it is working towards transparency and correctness.
So we expect further steps forward from this point of view, because it is obviously not entirely acceptable, especially with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is aware of the fact that the Council of Ministers of the European Communities has not yet taken a decision on this matter.
Mr President, we were in Ramallah when the news came that Europe had taken a new decision on the Middle East peace process.
We have seen the smile of hope of the Palestinian representatives.

These were days of intense emotions and suffering, carved on the faces of children, attached to the grates of the windows of their homes, on the street of Hebron, the ghost road that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman who was driven from her occupied home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent in the garden of her former home, the suffering of those Palestinians who had built a farm with European funds, then destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but the Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, a passport.
The Council of Europe's decision is a significant step forward, but action must be taken immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the last day of the visit, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the delegation of the European Parliament, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this issue the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, should intervene to make the protest of democratic Europe heard.

I thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation, because in the days we were in Palestine, the weak in Palestine were able to see and hear the face and the words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is engaged in the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.

When it comes to the fight against terrorist offences, it is necessary to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures taken to combat terrorism are adequate and effective.

The fundamental rights of defence and procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the institutions of the Union, even when defining lists of persons and entities, in this case linked to certain criminal offences.
It is equally essential that these measures are subject to adequate democratic and parliamentary control, as the Treaty of Lisbon rightly prescribes.

It is therefore clear that, as the Parliament's Legal Service has also stated, any measure of this kind will have to follow the codecision procedure, allowing the representatives of European citizens to play their legislative and guarantee role to the full.
Mr President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our disagreement with the Iranian Government.
I would just like to emphasize, as I have not been quoted here, that the violation of civil rights is one of the most serious in the world, and that of young people.
Having the Iranian government also signed the United Nations Convention for the Protection of the Child, it instead continued capital punishment against minors.
I would like Baroness Ashton, on the one hand, to undertake, after this debate, to indicate a common line for the whole of Europe and for the whole of the European Parliament.

On the one hand, the European Parliament on the events in Iran, and on the other hand, that the Interparliamentary Commission, with the Iranian Government, should take note of the fact that the course has been changed.

I participated with my friends Scuria and Tatarella in the protest we had made against the Commission, which, however, also made an official statement stating that it wanted to go to Iran, having instead asked in a peremptory manner that there be a possibility of meeting the opposition and dialogue with it.

I would like the Commission to turn the page now and have a relationship of help, support and comparison with the representatives of the opposition in exile, not least Mrs Miriam Rajabi, who represents this reality.
This should be done by the European Community rather than by sanctions.

Ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking in order to highlight the seriousness of the deindustrialisation situations that are affecting various Sicilian industrial poles, in particular the automotive sector of the MERESE group, the Fiat group and the petrochemical sector of the GELAS group.
The term "Iranian" is damaged by competition from the low-wage system within some EU countries, and frozen by Asian competition.
With regard to the processes of serious deindustrialisation taking place in large areas of the Union, I believe that the time has come to reconsider the line of non-intervention.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter and that it has not yet taken a decision on this matter.
This exhortation is addressed in particular to the European Commission and to Commissioner Tajani for Industry.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the subject of good tax governance, although it has always been of great importance, has become even more relevant and relevant after the great economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
This has been discussed and continues to be discussed at international, G20 and European summits, particularly when it comes to the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All this is important, it is a sign of commitment and will, but we must not delude ourselves that an announcement is enough.
A serious and continuous policy is needed.
There are still many problems.
Is it really still too easy to buy or open a ghost company to evade tax?
Just go online, there are thousands of websites that offer companies to buy, even in European Union countries.
And often an email with a photocopy of the scanned passport is enough to open a company.
The practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation must be put to an end.
This report, which I am presenting, is based on the European Commission's communication on good tax governance of 28 April 2009.
The report goes in the direction of putting forward concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The European Union's priority must be the fight against tax havens, tax evasion and the illicit flight of capital.
Hence the principle of good governance, which is based on transparency, exchange of information, cross-border cooperation and fair tax competition.
The point is that there is a need for ever greater cooperation and tax cooperation in the European Union.
The general objective we must set ourselves is to achieve an automatic exchange of information on a global and multilateral scale, starting, of course, with the European Union.
We must abolish banking secrecy in the countries of the European Union, put an end without further delay to the derogation regime for banks in the euro area.
temporary tax exemption, which authorises the application of a tax deduction to the source, often evaded or underestimated, instead of the exchange of information.
I do not want to go into the concrete proposals contained in the report.
I would like to emphasize that we still need a few points in particular: to extend the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, to combat VAT fraud, to establish a public register of the Union.
The Commission is committed to ensuring that the European Union takes account of persons or companies that have set up companies or opened accounts in tax havens.

It is also necessary for the European Union to speak with a single language at international level and to fight for the improvement of the OECD rules to achieve automatic exchange of information instead of exchange on request.

Commissioner Kovacs, you have also heard the other reports, we need a strong commitment from the Commission and we need at this moment that the new Commission, at the time of the exchange of deliveries, be emphasized these priorities.
We will hold the Council and the Commission accountable for their work.
I would like to thank my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution to this work, which I hope will be approved by Parliament.

Madam President, I must admit that when we talk about the fight against terrorism, discussing only intelligence and technology, I always get the impression that we refrain from examining the issue in an inadequate way, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not time to tackle the problem of terrorism by focusing on the heart of the matter rather than limiting ourselves to its external phenomenology?

To tackle the heart of the problem means, for example, to recognise that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I ask myself and I ask this Parliament do we want to discuss terrorism?
So let this Parliament have the courage to face up politically to a debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and on the tendency to share Western values, rights and freedoms.
In this connection, I have put a question to the Committee on the Whole to encourage this House to discuss the matter openly.
It seems that there is no will to deal with the subject.
I ask myself and I ask you, ladies and gentlemen of all the political groups, if not on these issues, on which others should the political agendas of the peoples of Europe be pronounced?

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the conclusion of the negotiations with Croatia by 2010 is a possible objective and the report is a good opportunity to underline in a balanced way the progress and steps yet to be taken.
Now it is justice, the sector in which still need to be decisive reforms.
It is not enough, in fact, to complete the necessary systemic reforms and to pass new laws and to cooperate as necessary with the Criminal Court for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a real legal culture and mentality in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary, the central problem, the training, recruitment and career of magistrates, the absence of various types of conditions imposed by the government on judges, become crucial.
I call on the Commission to consider the need for decisive measures in this respect in the final phase of the negotiations.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Croatia's accession to the European Union emphasises the consolidation of a European identity capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe without obscuring, but rather integrating the specificities of its many souls.

The Republic of Croatia has made considerable efforts to meet the required parameters, in particular in the fight against organised crime through new anti-mafia measures, but needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further steps can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to harmonize with what is provided for in the first Protocol to the European Convention on Human Rights signed in Paris in 1952, assessing the restitution to the legitimate owners of nationalized property.
Mr President, once again recently in Italy there has been an environmental disaster, the Lambro River and the Po River.
Recently, the Court of Justice of Luxembourg condemned Italy for the danger to public health, for an unlawful waste disposal and for not being able to control the collection of waste in Campania.
And the news of these days of the increase in leukemias in Taranto through ILVA, as well as the depletion of asbestos in schools in Crotone, as well as dioxin in Campania.
It's a continuous environmental disaster.

I firmly ask the Commission what it intends to do to ensure that the Italian Government complies with the standards of the European Union directives, in particular with regard to the judgment of the Court of Justice the other day.
The city of Naples has been exposed to the public for weeks and for many months all over the world.

Mr President, this debate is not ritual, but it wants to be very concrete and to ask clear and precise questions about how many resources to take, and I hope that Parliament hopes that the answers will be equally clear and precise today and in the next Council on 12 and 25 March.

We want to say firmly to the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge before the world, has a duty of coherence today if it does not want to lose credibility.
It must do everything possible to achieve these objectives.

We must know very well that talking about a low-emission economy means a kind of Copernican revolution for the production system, it means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential for our production system, for European industry, to remain competitive.
I mean, in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligence is ready, the capabilities are there, the will is there, it's about turning this engine on.
It must be done by everyone, said the Commissioner, said the Council, by the Member States, by entrepreneurs, by private forces.
But I believe that the essential task of bringing together this comprehensive partnership is that of the European Union.
In order to tackle the employment problem in a constructive way, the EU's three key words in its relations are to react, evolve and protect.

To react, that is to say, to abandon the celebratory tones of European propaganda in order to tackle in a concrete way the problems facing the citizens of the EU, ensuring a direct link between the world of training and the needs of the market and the territory, and re-qualifying young people for manual professions.

To evolve, that is to say, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of enterprises and those of workers in favour of a labour market in which contractual forms are flexible to respond to the instability of market demand.

The Member States must therefore assess immigration policies on the basis of the real need for immigration, and with 23 million unemployed, they should consider the possibility of blocking extra-Community immigration for a few years.
I see no other way to protect our work and our social system.
We need concrete action, courage and decentralization.

Mr President, this is an oral amendment to paragraph 13, which calls on the Commission to verify in the current situation the possibility of providing humanitarian aid in the event of a situation arising.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to emphasize once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption which I proposed together with four other Members and which was approved by half of the European Parliament, a way of committing the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on corruption.

I have returned from a visit to Greece on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control and certainly one of the reasons for the Greek structural crisis is also due to the waste of public money, a situation which also occurs in Italy.

Corruption, as it emerges these days, corruption that revolves mainly through the illegal management of public money, in relation to a part of politics and a part of entrepreneurs, and the organized crime of white collar workers.

It is important that the European Parliament should put all its pressure on the Commission, on the Member States, that Member States which do not comply should be sanctioned and that the European institutions which must control corruption and the fight against organised crime should be strengthened.
As far as the male and female population is concerned, we know very well that this difference is even more pronounced in the field of autonomous activities.
In fact, too often women have been forced to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of the assumption of the role and the workload that comes from absolute devotion to the family.
In order to solve this problem, I believe it is necessary to take measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but keeping a close eye on the family's moral star.

Freeing women from the agonizing dilemma of choosing between the role of mother, wife and entrepreneur means making the burden of family work less burdensome and going straight to the concrete problems through positive and specific measures of support for the family.
Putting the family at the centre, otherwise any package of measures will be a disjointed set of interventions, which in the end will be useless.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are here today to talk about organ transplantation, which is certainly one of the most positive aspects of progress in health.
But on the other hand, it opens up a whole series of problems with regard to the rights of the donor and the patient, which must be addressed on the ethical, social, legal and economic level.

The aim is to activate a virtuous path that addresses the serious imbalance between the need and the quantity of organs available, without, however, undermining the principle of free and voluntary donation.
It is also important to ensure that the quality and safety of organs for transplantation is guaranteed by measures that combine confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that, in a context of cross-border trade and significant differences between transplant systems adopted in the different Member States, such objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this respect, I believe that it would be very important to set up a European database and to adopt common quality and safety standards.
However, we must be careful not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create additional bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently being done in a correct and effective way.
It would not only be against our objectives.

Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has done on the accession of the European Union to the Convention on Human Rights, which is the first of its kind in the world.

It is a benefit for the citizens of Europe, because it will create a new court outside the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and the Member States.

In accordance with the principle of democracy, the European Union and the Member States must always have the right to defend themselves, and I believe that it is essential that every nation that accedes to the Convention should have a judge who explains the context of each appeal.

I believe that the European Parliament should have an informal body to coordinate the exchange of information between Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is important that Parliament is also consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, as they have the right to know what their rights are.

I therefore believe that it is essential that the Council of Europe and the European Union take into account the development of guidelines, with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications of accession.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 170 measures in five years, numbers too ambitious for a programme without a real connotation, especially on some subjects.
On immigration, the programme, beyond the official documents, shows an embarrassing beauty. What's the point of promising to strengthen bodies and agencies if there's no political strategy?

A really useful strategy which must be based on a number of firm points: the fight against illegal immigration along the southern border, the sharing of anti-clandestine measures among all European states, policies of agreements with third countries and, above all, the recognition that immigration at the time of the crisis is not a resource.
We read in Parliament's homepage that more than 20 per cent of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with 25 million unemployed, the Commissioner for the Interior says that the issue of migration must be based on solidarity.
Today the priority is to give work to our citizens, everything else is good rhetoric that does not help the integration of immigrants, much less our people.
I would like to take this opportunity to remind the Presidency that it must intervene because the links are very important.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
I ask you to act appropriately.

The financial and economic crisis of these months and years, the new Treaty of Lisbon with its new tasks, the challenge we have faced with Europe 2020 require the mobilisation of new and abundant financial resources.
The paradox we are also witnessing in this debate is that in the present state both the Commission and the Council seem to us to be silent, unable to choose and to make decisions.
But we know that if we want to get out of the difficult economic and social phase, if we want to tackle the great environmental bottlenecks, the development of cohesion policy and the
In the next few years, we need to invest more in Europe and in the functioning of Europe, and therefore in the essential functioning of Europe, that is, in its budget.
That is why we must not be afraid to discuss, even in a period of financial constraint, investing more in resources.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
But this is the challenge we face.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament has been called upon, as we know, to express itself definitively on food information to consumers.
It must be said at once that this was an objectively laborious, long and controversial legislative process which could not be shortened.

It is, in fact, a question of harmonising Community food law through legislation that makes information transparent to consumers, avoiding inducing them to make confusing or potentially harmful choices about their health.

Mr Sommer's report, which acknowledges the effort made to synthesise multiple needs, is therefore intended to remedy the controversies and various information systems in force in the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national legislation still differs in the designation of the nature of the products put up for sale, creating a different system from country to country and also fuelling unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
It sought, on the basis of the European Commission's proposal, to give a new twist to the legislation in force, involving on the one hand the food industry and on the other the consumers.
At the same time, the report commits the European food industry to clarifying mandatory indications, indications and presentations of nutritional values.

In a globalised market, the European Union could not escape the burden by innovating food legislation to better protect food trade and to safeguard it from increasingly invasive and savage international competition.

It is not new that we hear more often about the dangers of food products that indirectly lead to a lack of indications that often do not meet the food requirements that are still packaged as food and benefits for human health.
Commissioner, we wanted this oral question and a parliamentary resolution to clarify with the Commission that we are not going to accept the amendments.
In the context of the Stockholm programme, it is very important to build a European legal culture, widespread in our territory.

I would like to say at once that this is important, but also that in view of the communication which the Commission will have to produce on future pilot projects, as has been said, we would like to clarify some concepts.
First of all, that the consultations begin soon, the consultations in the meantime with Parliament, and that they reach the initial stage when the idea is first drawn up.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing these future projects, because we are not too late when the projects have already been fully formulated.
I say this because we have some in-depth observations to make.
Considering that the national magistrate, the lawyer of the individual States, is today a decisive step towards the construction of Europe.
Because by interpreting national rights as a European key, it also provides the conditions for resolving conflicts and regulating the daily lives of citizens.
It is a European sensitivity for all those who live in these territories, so that they can touch with their hands the European Union and the European Union.
It is one of the advantages that the introduction of European elements in all the rights of the States and therefore, above all, in Community law, makes citizens live better.
They offer real advantages in answering a number of problems that would otherwise remain unsolved.
I would like to say with this that we would like to turn the plant around a bit.
For example, we would not agree that these projects should be in the Erasmus style, because the number of magistrates and lawyers involved in the Erasmus style projects would be
It is very low, as it can only be, because of the high costs of physical mobility in this field and therefore not very relevant in the overall context of the judiciary.
But the most important question concerns the term familiarization of courses, which we have introduced in our document.

Magistrates are not schoolchildren sitting on school benches being taught, they are mature, highly professional people with little time at their disposal, not easily moved, but they carry their own bags.

They need to be stimulated so that their knowledge is measured against the new problems of European law and European culture, creating conditions for trade that are predominantly virtual rather than formal.

We need to use physical tools, using technology, the network and the various opportunities that can determine these exchanges, and starting not so much from a general approach, but from the individual cases, from the individual problems that magistrates and lawyers face.
It is a new set of rules which must stimulate the professional growth of these legal practitioners within their effectively stimulating framework.
They must contribute to the autobiographical reflection of their life, of what they have learned, in order to respond to the challenges that Europe is facing in positive terms.
As you can see, Mr President, Commissioner, we intend to put something new into the tradition of the courses that have been taken so far and which seem to us to be ineffective in this respect.

We need to know how many funds are available and which ones, to express doubt about the idea, as was written in the communication, of a central European institution governing this process, because we are for a movement from below and not for centralisation.
We are dealing with a new approach.

What we want to mean, however, is that if we do not form a European mentality among the magistrates, among the lawyers, who in this way offer their services to justice and to the citizens who ask for it, we will not make Europe.
So this is not just an important charter for European justice, it is an important charter for the whole development of European unity.
Ladies and gentlemen, the proposal on the rights of passengers travelling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, in particular the disabled or those with reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should guarantee passengers, as is the case in the rail and air sectors.
