The position at second reading is aimed at establishing a number of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I agree with the line of the rapporteur, Mr Cancian, who I thank for the excellent work done, and I believe that the scope of the regulation should be changed, excluding regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and proper to guarantee the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations or delays in departure, as had already been decided at first reading by Parliament.

The question of passenger rights information is equally important, since it would be useful to provide passengers with information on coincidences with other modes of transport, which will also ensure dialogue between bus and rail passenger transport services.

As regards disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility, maximum protection must be guaranteed and I would propose a 24-hour time limit instead of 48 hours in order to require assistance as well as greater guarantees for the reimbursement and replacement of instruments that guarantee the mobility of persons with disabilities in the event of loss or damage.
In addition, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure improved to make it accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, to promote intermodality, but above all to improve passenger travel conditions.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sterckx, for his excellent work on this report, which deals with extending free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share with the rapporteur the purpose of this directive, namely to exempt all transport of maritime goods within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, in order to have a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate in a satisfactory manner, but also that the various simplification systems are applied at the same time.
This is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of the entire European maritime area without borders, to make maritime freight transport more attractive and to use it in the best possible way.

The harmonisation of administrative procedures between Member States will allow for more fluid navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will boost maritime freight traffic, which today accounts for less than 10% of the total.
To this day, navigation continues to be hampered by the administrative formalities imposed on it.
Electronic systems should therefore be put into operation as soon as possible, as this would allow for a faster data exchange system.

In addition, interoperability is important for achieving real administrative simplification, as the transmission of information by e-mail is not entirely efficient and is useless if information systems are not technically interoperable.
As far as the language is concerned, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be more rapid, causing less confusion and less administrative delays.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Mr Kramer, because we all know that we have really achieved something that sometimes seemed unexpected.
I would like to recall that this dossier was really considered a dossier at risk of conciliation procedure.
So we have also heard from the Commissioner that it is clear to everyone that we are facing a work that has been complex and has taken a long time.
Just think of a 1996 directive, and this work leads us to the fifth and most important amendment to the Industrial Emissions Directive.
Only these few figures, I believe, tell us all the shortcomings and even the defects of this legislation.

A directive of difficult implementation I would like to recall that nine Member States are affected by infringement procedures and with an scope of application so extensive that it is sometimes even inappropriate.

All this, we must not hide it, has involved a great deal of effort, it has called for the resignation of all the institutions involved, of all the political groups, of all the national delegations, and it has often put us in front of really difficult choices.

But I am here tonight to say with conviction that I believe we have achieved the best possible results in protecting competition, protecting the environment, European industrial and employment policy.
We really have, on the one hand, a directive which imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other hand a directive which also allows for the necessary flexibility.

I really hope that the results of this merger will be, in the immediate future, also the reduction of administrative burdens and, in the medium term, the improvement of environmental performance and the strengthening of European industry.
Mr President, I would like to emphasize the situation in which the Church is faced with a reality in which for too long it has not been given the importance it deserved.
This means that instability in Central Asia is unfortunately growing, while hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, are particularly fragile.

The Kyrgyz Republic has suffered in the last month from very hard clashes that will leave, at least in the immediate future, an inheritance of interethnic hatred that will make the stabilization of the country even more difficult than it was before.
The task of the international community and of the European Union in particular, as has already been said, is to assist the Kishida as much as possible in three respects:

Secondly, through the longest-term economic aid possible for the European Union in the context of the crisis, the European Union must be able to provide the necessary financial support to the victims of the crisis.

The European Union has adopted a strategy for Central Asia and the instruments implemented in this context, through political support to support the process of returning to constitutional legality and the establishment of a genuine rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, which has been held in Greece since 28 June, in obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the road to a return to a constitutional order.

The electoral process on 28 June, among other things, received a positive judgment from the OSCE observation mission, which obviously took account of the special conditions in which the referendum took place.
The new constitutional order of the Church will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than a presidential one.
This may make it possible to take better account of the country's varied ethnic composition and the need to gather the consensus of the various components of such a fractured and composite country.
The European Union and Kyrgyzstan are bound by a partnership and cooperation agreement, which provides for regular meetings of a parliamentary cooperation committee.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a democratically elected Kyrgyz parliament.
The crisis, as I have already said, needs stability and our political and economic help immediately.
Mr President, the European Council, for which no one voted, today also has a rotating presidency in the hands of a government that is distrusted by its own citizens.

This would be enough to understand why Europe is experiencing a profound crisis, a Europe which is now a political paradox in the hands of a political elite in which citizens do not recognise themselves.
The programme of the Belgian non-presidency deals with structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability and competitiveness, and the chosen instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
The current crisis, however, should push Europe to very different ingredients from those that led to the bankruptcy.

A general rethink is needed, because the crisis is not a mirror of decline, but rather the death certificate of the European social model that European propaganda would instead like to provide as a cure.
Today Europe is a huge building that is collapsing on itself because of the weight of democracy, centralism and the obstacles to free enterprise.
To get out of the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralisation, less bureaucracy, more concreteness and attention to the real problems of citizens.
All the rest will only accelerate the inevitable decline.
I would like to emphasize in my speech how the progressive erosion of the incomes of European farmers at the expense of the growing needs of the European farmers is a major problem.
The profit margins of the agribusiness sector are creating a worrying economic marginalisation of agricultural workers, with consequent dismissals from the same activities.
A change of course is therefore required, which the European Commission itself recognises and which the report on the examination of the Chamber this morning has made clear.
The adoption of this morning's report, which I want to express my support for, is underlined with broad motivations and suggestions, including legislative and departmental ones.
It is necessary to combat global speculation in raw materials and to ensure the safety of supplies.

In addition, better price transparency must be ensured, which not only brings justice to farmers' dignity but also corrects the strong balances of bargaining power and avoids abuses between different operators.
Agriculture must be reconfirmed as the sector of economic and social stability and regain power in the EU's commercial context.
Mobilism and myopia is the diagnosis of the malaise that affects Europe 27 today.

Immobilism is because if in Italy one in four young people is unemployed and there are 16 million unemployed in the euro area, it is also because the noise of the euro propaganda of recent months has not been followed by any concrete effective action.

Myopia because Europe, in indicating the way out of the crisis, has not only represented the usual recipe, but has completely lost sight of the most authentically territorial dimension of economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by putting the territory at the centre of political action, only by respecting its peculiar cultural vocations, can European development and employment policies start again, nourished by the natural energies that each geographical area expresses, districts, small and medium-sized enterprises and crafts.
To solve the employment problem, we must first think small: invest in local authorities and give preference to subsidiarity, protecting a heritage of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the European Brussels Eagle does not steer its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the Euro project is a certainty.
Mr President, in the construction of a Europe of rights, freedom of information, pluralism of information, independence of information have a central place.
Has the Commissioner realised that there is a country in the European Union, among other things, which is a founder of the Treaty of Rome of the European Union, where there is no
What is the pluralism of information, where a President of the Council directly or indirectly controls public and private television and printed paper?
What democratic electoral competition can there be in a country where a president, the Council and a political party control the media?
What democracy can there be in a country where a law is being passed in the last few days that does not allow journalists to publish court records?
Other than Watergate, other than the regime's guardian press, the living room barbecue, what democratic country is it where the Internet wants to be controlled?
What a democratic country it is, where those who oppose the single thought are put in the corner and the free expression of thought and dissent is not guaranteed.

We are not describing the Sudan of Bocassa, Romania of Ceausescu and Italy of Berlusconi, where unfortunately this is happening, also because the European Commission does not have the courage to make a sense of an autonomous and free position vis--vis the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important step, but it would be a major step forward.

It is appropriate for the Commission to carry out an impact assessment, as some of my colleagues who preceded me have pointed out, of the opening up of the postal market in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the rights of European citizens living in hard-to-reach areas, such as mountain or rural areas, so that they can receive mail regularly, and what instruments does the Commission intend to adopt to ensure that this happens?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be used to justify the problem of social dumping.
It is up to the Member States to implement the directive and they have all the tools to do so.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate on readmission agreements cannot escape the now thorny issue of the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that part of the agreement is focused on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because, to date, the Commission has said little about it, despite the fact that the Treaty of Lisbon requires the Commission itself to inform Parliament in a timely manner.
Libya, as is well known, has not signed the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, much less has it so far shown itself to behave in accordance with international law.

I am thinking of the case of Eritrean immigrants inhumane detention in the Libyan center of Brak or the closure of the offices in Akhnur, but I am thinking above all of what happened last week when a motorcycle of the Libyan Republic opened fire.

The European Union has been accused of violating the agreement signed between Libya and Italy against an Italian fishing vessel of the Mazzala del Vallo Navy, which is present in international waters, on the grounds of the presence of illegal immigrants.

It provides, inter alia, for the rejection of immigrants to Libya without provisions on the right to seek asylum and individual examinations on a case-by-case basis, and also for the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.
Since part of the agreement is also secret in this case, I wonder whether the Commission is aware of the content, if it does not consider it necessary, in the specific case, to ask for explanations.
I would like to ask the Libyan authorities to open fire on boats if there is suspicion that they are transporting irregular migrants, because if they were, such provisions would be unacceptable.

On the economic side, it is positive for Europe to deepen trade relations with its fast-growing neighbours, but the EU has always pursued, at least in words, a trade policy towards third countries, taking into account social and humanitarian aspects.
We must then enforce these clauses with firm determination towards Turkey, a country which is re-Islamizing and in which the condition of women is gradually deteriorating, with more than
The country has seen more than 200 women killed in 2009 in cases of domestic violence, a country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamic extremists.
In the report, Parliament encourages Turkey to take a leading role in promoting fair and open trade.
In any case, if trade policy is to be, it must be, but it must never become the horse of Troy to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this measure is intended to strengthen and rationalise the European Union's pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious and objective proposals in the McAvan reports, amending Regulation No 726 and Directive No 2183 respectively.
This is possible thanks to close and efficient consultation between the Council and the European Parliament and the relevant parliamentary committees.
I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is prepared to accept the amendments tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection.

Simplification, transparency and rationalization can be considered the key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health on the basis of harmonised standards throughout Europe.

In fact, it refers to a wide range of interventions, ranging from a better definition of the roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational actors concerned to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient, to which the

The Commission recognises a key role in the system for strengthening the transparency of information on medicinal products safety, for simplifying communication, registration and assessment of alleged negative side effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system needs to be improved, also through closer cooperation at European, national and regional level.
Effective participation at all three levels will ensure a fruitful exchange of information on the side effects of medicinal products.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information for patients, national authorities and healthcare providers.
Mr President, it is precisely in these days that the elections here in Brussels have taken place.

Many representatives of municipalities and regions have discussed how to deal with the serious problems facing the lives of our cities, with the old and new needs affecting workers, families and small and large productive enterprises.
The economic crisis that has hit our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to give adequate answers to a new serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone has understood that cohesion policy has on so many occasions been the only concrete instrument in the hands of the territories to try to give answers.
We can therefore say that cohesion policy has been an essential lever for the process of European integration in all regions in recent years.
Now we are redefining this policy for the post-2013 period, so we are at a turning point.
That is why it is vital to avoid some risks.
The first fundamental one is that of its renationalization, it would be a serious step backwards.

Secondly, it is necessary to ensure, in the construction of the financing budget, an adequate level of both the weakest realities and the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify procedures for those who have proved efficient and to make it easier to punish those who have not.
We expect the Commission to go in this direction.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the road to a Europe of women's measure is still long and difficult.
Statistics speak for themselves: the global crisis has hit the labour market, putting female employment to the test, which in 2008 fell by an additional 7 percentage points.

Despite the provocations that periodically fill a euro propaganda in the form of consensus on equal opportunities and employment, to date no concrete measures have been taken to guarantee a real achievement for women as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not just periodically change its label.

The directive which aligns the maternity leave institution in Europe is therefore good, but the choice to treat the maternity leave supplementary leave, which is equally important, on the margins of this matter in the same report is inefficient.

Greater integration of women is not only a moral value, but also a strategic objective for the sustainability of the much-publicized European social model, which continues to fail to convince me of the lack of results.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rapporteur of the Committee on Development, Mr Mitchell, has asked me to replace him because he cannot be here today.
I thank him for the work he has done, with his usual punctuality and for the quality of his proposals, which have been unanimously welcomed by the Committee on Development.
As I will say, but above all as Mr Michel has done so far, I am convinced that the report can be voted on by a large majority.
But I now come to the report.
In 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation No 1905 establishing a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had asked Parliament to approve an amendment allowing non-governmental organisations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
It's a proposal we accepted.
But the Cooperation and Development Regulation also contains the rules for the implementation of the European Union's development policy.
These rules provide that when the Commission is to provide funding, it must follow the procedures of the Committee.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine these financing proposals and, if the Commission exceeds its powers, Parliament can then adopt resolutions to ask the Commission to change the decisions in question.

Since 2006 alone, Parliament has considered that in at least 12 cases the Commission has exceeded its enforcement powers, but only in three of these cases has the Commission actually amended or withdrawn its proposal for a decision.
Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Committee on Development proposed to apply the delegated act procedure provided for in Article 290 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that Parliament would have a more relevant role, at least in the strategic financing decisions to be taken by the European Commission.
Indeed, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in some well-defined cases Parliament can delegate the power to take strategic decisions to the Commission.
In our view, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

It is a choice that belongs to the legislator, and then what sectors should be given priority in the financing of education, health, environmental protection, the capacity of good governance, the development of small businesses?
And how can we ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the choices and the matters in which the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has ever played in the past.
It is here that the legislator must give precise instructions to the executive.
And this is precisely the direction in which I believe the demands of the citizens of Europe are finally going.
I really hope that there will be as much consensus as possible on this report by Mr Mitchell.
I'm going to talk to the rapporteur.

We need to overcome the phase of good intentions and give a new impetus to a strategy that will be a steering wheel for the growth and development of the European Union, filling the enormous delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, the fight against climate change and pollution.
Just this morning our colleague Mr Pirillo called Parliament back on another catastrophic event that took place in recent days in the city of Paola in Calabria.

The Commission will have to show concrete action, not only by working with governance instruments but also by implementing timely legislative measures, drawing the necessary lessons from the mistakes of the past, due to an approach that is often too sectoral.

It is well known that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and demanding period of time, which cannot tolerate any burden of attention and which needs adequate investment.

It is involved in governance mechanisms, both at interinstitutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, including the Mediterranean, because of the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It will therefore be essential to understand the management of the Mediterranean basin as a common heritage for all river states, based on the principle of the

Otherwise, the increasingly widespread practice of unilateral declarations of exclusive economic zones or similar in the Mediterranean Sea, in addition to not being in line with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would give the idea of effective and shared governance.
I would remind you that just a month ago this interpretation by Libya produced a real armed assault on the European fishery and it would be wrong to argue that this is a purely Italian-Libyan affair.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank Mr Meissner for his report on the integrated maritime policy, and I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and construction and to protect coastal regions, as well as to promote innovation and research.
Today, maritime transport plays a key role in trade.
Cooperation between small and large ports facing the same sea basin and which can facilitate more fluid trade should therefore be encouraged.
In addition, to ensure intermodality, investment must be made in port and back-to-port infrastructure, especially ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I think it is important not to overlook another issue, namely port security.

It is necessary to homogenise all security measures within all European ports in order to better protect maritime transport and to avoid unfair competition at the expense of those ports which, instead, in order to ensure greater security, have to face greater costs.
Mr President, 30 years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sarawi people, today it is denying that there is disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet in Western Sahara there are dead and wounded of a population that claims only the right to live freely in its own land.
Morocco has substantially closed its borders to anyone who can witness these events.
No information and no deputies.
A French Member of Parliament and our colleague Mr Mayer have been denied access.
Europe is passively assisting.
There is no sign of the Commission's communication, which makes us subordinate to the UN mediation, which continues to fail as in the last 30 years.
There is no position of Mrs Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
We must react by taking a stand in Parliament.
We must react to Morocco by stopping any initiative on trade agreements, starting with the renewal of fisheries agreements.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my speech does not want to be the usual Eurosceptic rhetorical exercise, but an impulse for the EU to start paying more attention to the content than to the container and to abandon propaganda in favour of concreteness.
After the failure of the Lisbon strategy, Europe has developed a new slogan, EU 2020, but in fact it has not given any innovative response to the employment problems.

The data confirm that the unemployment rate in Europe is 9.6, that of young people is 20.2, and in Italy, the third largest net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9 young people without a job.

In the Europe I would like to see, there is no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but efficient investments so that the training offer prepares professionals for the sectors of the internal market where there are concrete employment opportunities.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in vocational training, a symbol of the excellence of our territories.
The world of craftsmanship offers a unique employment potential and heritage of knowledge, to which the task of supporting the competitiveness of the Europe system must be entrusted.

Mr President, Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council, the European will to set ambitious targets for the next climate change conference is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will shape the future of our planet.
But that is precisely why, ladies and gentlemen, we must be more realistic and cautious in our expectations.

The preparatory international negotiations for the Cancun Conference, as far as we know, have not only not made significant progress towards a comprehensive agreement, but have confirmed suspicions and resistance to the commitments made in Copenhagen.
It has already been mentioned, but I would also like to mention China here.
China, for example, is allowing itself an increase in its emissions of 5 billion tons of CO2 by 2020, with consequences that could be offset.
And perhaps not at all, but an attempt at compensation, with only a 100 reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This fact not only makes the proposal for an unconditional reduction of 30%, which we strongly oppose, unrealistic, but it also leads many independent observers to speculate that there will be a significant increase in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at least risky and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and sketch suggestive but unrealistic scenarios where the unknowns inevitably reflect on the size of the costs.

The aim is for the European Union to bring to Cancun a shared, realistic and sustainable proposal, because it is always and in any case preferable to have an agreement that produces concrete and tangible results rather than a proposal that produces tangible results.

It is not enough to have expectations inevitably destined to failure and to make the efforts of governments on major environmental issues increasingly unreliable in the eyes of international public opinion, and this would be a damage that is difficult to repair.

Mr President, I have only one regret in this House tonight, which is that we are discussing the Sarawis only because the Moroccans have invaded Tendopoli outside El Aaiun, and this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
Parliament should have matured its own will to discuss this issue, which has been withering on international tables for 30 years.
This is the most relevant political fact.
We have been forced to commit acts of violence, and not because we have decided autonomously to guarantee human rights.
Because what is it if not respect for human rights, the fact that there should be a referendum for self-determination?

It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is the strongest part of the relations, that we must strongly and with all the consequent acts ask that there be a will that can no longer be postponed.
We must try to build the conditions so that the mission, which is delicate and closed, Mr President, is not alone in building the conditions for a referendum which is constantly being postponed.
We must try to use all the means at the disposal of the European Union to condition this event and to ensure that this referendum does justice to the 30 years of suffering of a people.
Mr President, outside this question, outside this question, I wanted to put a problem to the Presidency.
I believe that someone has not yet fully understood the role of the European Parliament after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am forced to put a fundamental problem here: Commissioner Kallas refuses repeatedly to meet with the board of Sky and Space to discuss the SESAR project, which is of interest to everyone from the economic, environmental and security point of view.
I invite the Presidency to call Commissioner Kallas to the House and to explain what programme it intends to pursue in this area, which is very delicate and important for the European Parliament.

Ladies and gentlemen, the report under discussion certainly contains some positive elements.The general orientation is to simplify procedures, to reduce bureaucratic barriers for workers from third countries with a regular residence permit in a Member State.

However, just as a point of reflection, I would like to recall that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are unemployed because of the structural shortcomings of the European production system and because of the effect of a crisis that does not seem to end.

Even before the citizens of third countries who reside in our countries, Europe is committed above all to implementing economic, political and social measures which help our citizens to find or regain their jobs.
If Europe can provide jobs for its citizens, it will create a solid social base to adequately accommodate migration flows from abroad.
The motto must first of all be to grow Europe on its own feet and with its own strength.
The European Union is the only country in the world that has
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to date access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of third-country nationals.
Not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must move to ensure equal treatment for citizens of third countries who reside legally within the Member States and for beneficiaries of the refugee or person in need of international protection qualification, in accordance with Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.
It is necessary to avoid a growing demand for seasonal staff, for example, only because they are paid less or have different, lower costs than a European citizen recruited for the same job.

For example, the risk must be avoided that many multinationals move their headquarters to countries such as Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is more economical.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring equal treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions and social security is essential.
For this reason, I think it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees and selfemployed workers should be included in this directive.
Making a difference will become extremely dangerous.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the trafficking of human beings, according to estimates by international organisations and police agencies, is now the second largest source of profit for organised crime in the world, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that some 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution and forced labour.
This means that, first of all, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of enormous proportions is a battle for the security of our citizens, against illegality, against crime that generates crime.
In the face of a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly take drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various ways.
In order to combat this phenomenon, cooperation between Member States and between police authorities is necessary, but above all the certainty of penalties for traffickers.
They live in poverty and despair and are ready to leave their land for the promise of a better life that will not be realized.

Europe, then, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit itself more and with greater scruples so that these people can find acceptable living conditions in their countries.
Let us help them at home, it must be the guiding principle of European political action, so that our efforts are directed not only to repression but also to prevention.
I'm going to do it.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as Vice-President of the Committee on Development, I am concerned with the problems of many countries, especially in the African region, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled upon, if not sometimes even forgotten.

I returned just last Sunday from an official mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where, in addition to the institutional meetings, I wanted to meet with representatives of NGOs operating in the country and visit some of the centres where they work.
I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a tool of war, where armed groups continue to attack women and girls, and where rape is seen as a tool of war.
We must repeatedly commit mass rape and other systematic crimes against civil society, especially against women, the elderly and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of the Congo because it was a recent experience of mine, as I was saying, a very recent experience.
But the appeal I want to make is generally directed to the need for a strong and continuous condemnation of the brutal violations of women's rights.
The international community must significantly strengthen the funds allocated to women's protection initiatives and other forms of violence.
Violence, such as genital mutilation, is also a serious form of violation of human rights and the physical integrity of women.
The European Heritage Label is of fundamental importance for a continent which includes most of the UNESCO sites and which is a major contributor to the world heritage.
Finally, it highlights those natural, archaeological, urban and cultural sites which have played an important role in the history, culture and integration of the European Union.
The approval of the brand is an important step for the Union's cohesion process and is also educational and formative for cultural dialogue.
It can also be seen that this choice is a good omen for the new generations, who will increasingly have a common vision of the European heritage that can accumulate them historically and culturally.

I would like to thank the rapporteur for her efforts and congratulate her most warmly on the negotiations she has had with the Commission for the effective success of this initiative, which is so important for the future of the preservation of the environment.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, are a health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has serious repercussions, not just health for those who suffer from it.
But the costs of direct and informal care are high.
The Alzheimer's disease is not just affecting the people who are affected, but it is also affecting all those who care for the sick themselves.

A European response to the problem, global coordination between Member States, a synergy of concerted actions covering mainly the scientific and research field and taking responsibility for the environment are therefore needed.

the enhancement of the prevention, diagnosis and improvement of available, also innovative, treatments, as well as the dissemination of information among States on the results achieved within the same incremental levels of knowledge of the disease.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation is that the countryside, and in particular the city of Naples, is now universally and unfortunately at night all over the world, and the European Union has had to deal with the issue on several occasions.

In the face of this situation, which is now paradoxical from the Third World, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences it will face from the point of view of Community law and what economic sanctions it will eventually face if the waste crisis in Campania does not find a final solution in a short time.

I also ask whether the Commission can provide in detail the data on the European funds that have so far been managed by the Campania region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, when we talk about emergencies, we usually talk about dramatic, extreme situations which, however, find a solution in reasonable times.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than 15 years, there is obviously something that doesn't work.
The Italian Government has tried in recent years to do its utmost to resolve the year-long issue of the waste collection and disposal cycle.
The blame is mainly to be blamed on the local authorities, the countryside, and their total inability or unwillingness to work to find a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond doubt that the conditions in which Naples and Campania are poured are due to the laxity which has characterized for so many years the municipality, the province and the regions in the management of the waste cycle.
If differentiated collection is not done where it is the first essential element of a waste management plan that works, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send the army, as happened a few weeks ago, but other times before, to replace hundreds of suddenly and simultaneously ill turbines, it obviously cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while in the rest of Italy things are going very differently, for example in my region of Veneto, where the harvest of the seasonal fruit has been done for years without problems and with a very high cycle rate, it means that the responsibilities of the emergency fall on the farmers.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so what is the Commission's position?
After the lies of the Berlusconi government, which intervened in 2008 by telling the Italians that the waste problem was over, the European Union is doing well.
to block funds to Italy until an eco-compatible waste cycle based on waste recycling and composting is presented.

It is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro, which is based once again on uncontrolled discharges, such as those from Chiaiano, Taverna del Rey, Terzignano, even in the Vesuvius National Park, or incinerators that produce deaths, tumors or a real health emergency.

Public money in Campania, in the environmental emergency of these 13 years, has consolidated the criminal relations between the politics of both the left and the right, the entrepreneurs and the Camorra.

And in environmental issues they are solved by the criminalization of dissent, by the criminalization of local communities, families and territory, as the Italian government has done, using the malganello to repress those who defend nature and territory.

An international refugee is a political refugee who, fearing persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, social affiliation or political opinion, finds himself outside the country of which he is a citizen.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecuted.

Despite the coverage offered for years by France, we are talking about a multi-murderer, perpetrator or commander of four murders, who hid behind the pretext of political struggle to escape to the slums.
It is shameful for a great country like Brazil to deny the extradition of a criminal who has never repented, recognizing him as a political refugee.
The Italian authorities and especially the families of the victims are demanding that this criminal be brought to justice.
In the face of President Lula's arrogance in banning extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic instruments at its disposal to ensure that Italy gets the delivery of Battisti, even at the cost of threatening the suspension of cooperation agreements with Brazil.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
The outburst of anger among the young and the poor in the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the unjust distribution of wealth and the limitations on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

North Africa is burning and demanding more democracy, more economy, more participation, more work, and looks with amazement at the old European continent, which is immobile, unable to cope with the social transformations that have taken place in that area and to develop real policies of progress and peace.
Europe should pay more attention to human rights and democracy, promote more dialogue, more cooperation and more real economic action.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the rejection of immigrants and the violent collaboration of countries like Libya, more investment, more reception and more aid, more Euromediterranean policy.
History asks us to do that.
The resolution adopted today by a majority on the emergency of waste in Campania is a very important signal.
The Campania emergency becomes a European emergency and is a decision in favour of the Campania citizens.
The European Union is saying no to the enlargement of funds that simply go to consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs and Camorra.
A plan for environmentally friendly waste, not uncontrolled landfills in national parks, not incinerators that produce dioxin, but recycling and environmentally friendly forms.
And it also says no to the criminalization of local dissent, so yes to legality.

It is an important turning point, a warning to the Berlusconi government and the regional government led by Caldoro, who until now have done nothing but talk and consolidate the crickets and the mafia bourgeoisie.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, counterfeit medicines are a problem which is becoming increasingly prevalent at international and Community level, both because of the increase in the number of cases and the increase in the improvement of cases themselves.
It is to these challenges that Mr Mathias' report would like to respond, the result of long and arduous negotiations.
The report, which we supported, defined a regulatory framework which, on the basis of more precise and detailed definitions, took into account the specificities of the sector.
We need to address all the actors, the moments and the resignations of the pharmaceutical chain, safety, traceability, obligations for the distribution chain, and we need to find a good compromise.
These are some of the aspects on which we must try to act in order to achieve the main objective of establishing more stringent rules, to prevent the entry of new products into the European Union.

We need to reduce the use of counterfeit medicines, to have a positive and more comprehensive regulatory framework to safeguard the health of citizens, protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.
Mr President, Egypt, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one, with millions of people demanding more equitable distribution of wealth, more justice, protesting against corruption.

From the transition of soldiers and the armed forces, we must move to true democracy, a new constitution, new elections, the abolition of the death penalty, more human prisons, social rights and freedoms.
It's going to be hard.
There are those who, in the name of an idea, think of using every means.
We want to believe the wonderful Egyptian people, who have never experienced democracy.

We want a secular democracy, with a clear separation between religious power and political power, a democracy that integrates minorities and realizes true rights, public health, social security, work.
Europe must support this path, but invest resources in order to promote the real development of Egypt, never more dictatorships, never more misery, never more poverty.
Mr President, Commissioner, I think that the issues related to the Mediterranean are entering an even more acute phase with this measure than the others we have completed.
I believe that the act we are debating today is much more important than the effects of the 2006 Community regulation.

I think that this also responds to some limitations of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has often left the broad fishing sectors to support the idea that Europe is doing its part, but other river countries are not doing theirs.
I think it is strategic for us to deal with the issue in this dimension and with these characteristics.
The work done by Mr Rivellini, which is very shared, I think deserves a formal thank you in this House.
Nevertheless, I have a clear feeling that the fact that we are unable to resolve this issue at first reading will lead to a second reading.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

Parliament essentially says that it is good that these delegated acts are at the head of the Commission and there is some resistance on the part of the Council, among other things, the absence today is also a significant absence.
But this act makes the idea mature in Parliament that maintaining the biodiversity, maintaining the fisheries of this important sea is also the operation of the future of the fishermen.
But having said that, I think that the phase we are facing must centralise the idea of codecision.
These delegated acts have their reason for being delegated and therefore conferred today on the Commission, but international agreements must maintain their role in Parliament when they are made.
Mr President, Commissioner, we have, in my view, two problems: one is the method and the other is the merit of this matter.

The method is that we are behaving through an artifice, for which we thank Mr Fraga, which is that of oral questioning, to talk about something which should instead be, after the Treaty of Lisbon, a right of this Parliament.
I think this practice must end, we cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a codecision process.
The codecision is when it is cultivated in the phases in which it matures.
Today we are having this debate, the treaty is over, it will go ahead and we will say yes or no at the end.
Well, this method needs to be converted.

On the merits, however, I would just like to emphasize, agreeing with many of my colleagues, the measurement of the effects of fisheries agreements, so that they are not just trade agreements through which we are going to buy cephalopods at one euro per kilo in Mauritania.

They must be able to measure both sustainability and, above all, the impact on the country's economy, to understand how many workers are changing, to understand the rate of innovation in artisanal fishing, to understand the use of these resources.
It is not just a pure and simple trade, but it is a fisheries agreement with all its implications.
The vote in favour of Mr Rivasi's report is the result of an evaluation of the management of H1N1 influenza.
The Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens at work is based on the principle of proportionality.
The report, after a long and positive phase of re-examination, focuses on cooperation, independence and transparency.

It aims for greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and the European institutions in order to be able to prepare for harmonised and coordinated risk management.
The objectives are to demonstrate the Member States' strategy for national influenza management plans, including vaccine stockpiles and the publication of names.

The European Commission has also proposed a number of measures to improve the quality of healthcare in the European Union, such as the establishment of expert institutes consulted by European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media responsible for disseminating public health messages.
That's why he got our vote in favor.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to date the recommendations adopted by the General Committee on Fisheries in the Mediterranean have been received in the Community legislation on a provisional basis, through annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These concern measures for the conservation, management, exploitation, control and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
However, the permanent nature of these recommendations requires a more stable legal instrument for their implementation in Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to receive the relevant recommendations by means of a single legislative act to which future recommendations may be added.
Today we have done this and this will improve the certainty of the law, while at the same time being an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties to the CGMP are obliged to ensure the full implementation of the agreed measures under the established agreement.

A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make such international measures directly applicable to individuals or legal entities at Community level and to ensure the certainty of tax law.
Mr President, I believe that the adoption of Mrs Podima's report represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, more advanced and stronger economic and fiscal policy in Europe.

It is now clear to everyone that there is an urgent need, as Europe, as coordination between the 27 countries, for economic and financial instruments capable of governing the economy and not just undergoing it.
For this reason, the proposal for the taxation of financial transactions has received a great deal of attention and discussion.
The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this rule is an important and significant fact, because for the first time it was not allowed to run and instead a step forward was taken.
I hope that the Commission and the Council will continue on this path.
I welcome the reports on equality between men and women and on women's poverty in Europe, and I am pleased that they have been discussed today, on the 100th anniversary of International Women's Day.

Despite the 2002 Directive on equal treatment between men and women in terms of access to work, training and promotion of occupational qualifications and working conditions, further efforts are still needed to achieve a correct balance.

It is enough to think that, despite the fact that the level of female education has increased greatly in recent years and the number of graduates is now higher than that of graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female sectors and are often less paid and occupy less positions of responsibility in all spheres of society.
Lack of access to care services for the unemployed, such as children, the disabled and the elderly, adequate leave schemes and flexible working arrangements prevent women from working.

I would like to close by recalling the women who are fighting for the most basic rights in the world and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are coming to the square today, inviting women to demonstrate without hijab.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I say to all those who have spoken that we are finally back to talking and I hope that we will act soon, also with timely choices of economic policy, of common industrial policy.
Thank you to the Lange report, to the excellent work done by the honourable Member and to President Tajani's communication.
The first is that the recovery and recovery of the European economy and the maintenance of employment is also, and perhaps above all, a recovery and support for all European citizens.
We have a manufacturing sector, the most advanced sectors and also the traditional ones, because there is a border that can still be crossed and it was not so discounted until some time ago.

Secondly, the recovery of the industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not being gambled on in the financial and tertiary sectors, but here again, and it is not too late to do so, we can set a challenge for Europe to regain competitiveness compared to the rest of the world in the industrial sectors.
Thirdly, the new industrial policy focuses more on factors than on sectors, on factors and instruments that can really promote new enterprises and new capacity for holding and updating.
So I think it is important to emphasize them, as these new factors on which credit must be acted on have been done.

Innovation, research, the need to accentuate in Europe the capacity for the technological transfer of research and innovation results into enterprises, new products and new modes and organisations of production.

We have to value a very peculiar fabric in our Europe, in some countries in particular, that of SMEs, that of the quality of enterprises, the quality of products, in short, the peculiarity of industry in Europe.
I think we should rediscover, say, these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries to innovate and change them.
Finally, the issue of territory, which is very important.
European policies succeed if they cross and find the territory capable of facing them.
So thank you very much and we look forward to working with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a short time.
Many goals have been achieved, but some battles have yet to begin.
Today, the urgency concerns women from other cultures living in Europe and the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimum standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this holiday without focusing on the issue of women in the Arab-Muslim world, otherwise we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them, but soon it will also become ours.
We cannot ignore the emergency numbers that are growing year by year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow up.
For a long time, there has been an increase in cases of violence of all kinds suffered by Muslim women within their own families.

That is why I have long called for, and I am calling for today, for Europe to implement policies aimed at combating Islamic radicalism, against forced marriages, against the rights of honour, against female genital mutilation and against domestic violence.
We European women and men must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic intellectualism.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform which took place on 12 September was unanimously recognised as an important step by Turkey towards Europe.
Of course, there are still many steps to be taken, and in this respect I express concern at the numerous arrests of journalists.

I would like to emphasize that Turkey is the European Union's seventh trading partner and that the European Union is Turkey's main trading partner and that trade, correctly interpreted over the centuries, has promoted the peaceful coexistence and knowledge of peoples.

I therefore welcome the remarkable progress made in boosting links between the European Union and Turkey, in particular those via the sea highways that cross the North Adriatic and the North Tyrrhenian Sea.
It is now used by more than 250 TIR routes in both directions, in connection with an important rail link and a truck-only subway from port to internal European destinations.
It has been possible to eliminate a conspicuous land traffic of trucks on the road and I hope that it will continue on that road.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with today's vote we have given a further impetus to the final solution to this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

In fact, I would like to recall that the more than 300 amendments tabled in the report have been transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all of which have been adopted with the aim of better defining the priority areas of the strategy and the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with its permanent task force, will have to ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and good practice, and the Member States should appoint a high-level government official who will act as a point of contact for the implementation of the strategy.
But we could have been even more incisive and less hypocritical if we had pointed out in the report the obligations and duties that the Roma community should still respect in the host countries.
This is my wish, that solutions be found soon to enable this community to coexist better in all the Member States.
Lampedusa has been invaded by tens of thousands of North Africans, whom the island could never, ever welcome.
Italy has been targeted by hundreds of illegal boats for weeks.
If we do not all react together, if the EU does not react, the wave of migration of people on the run will continue.
The illegals who have arrived in the last few months must be sent home.
But the Italian Government, beyond a few words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus from the unpredictable dimensions.
To this day, Brussels has been a disgraceful place, it has had a shameful behaviour that my fellow citizens can no longer tolerate.
Europe has left Italy alone to deal with an unprecedented emergency.

Instead, Europe must not only help Italy to repatriate illegal immigrants, but must also support the efforts of the Italian Government to prevent thousands and thousands of people, especially from Tunisia, from continuing to leave.

This is true of the Libyan refugees, on whom Europe must stand by Italy in its operations of electrification and logistics management, but above all it must commit itself to ensuring that refugees are hosted in all Member States.
The reception of those fleeing war cannot be limited to Italy alone.
It's time to end the chatter.
The European Union, if there is one, should strike.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with illegal immigrants, while France rejects them with shameful methods.
The illegals must be sent home, while all Member States must now commit themselves to welcoming Libyan refugees.
The issue of providing adequate financial resources to ensure the deactivation of nuclear power plants is a problem already faced by the European Union and its Member States.
It is a matter of great current interest today, in the light of recent international events and the subsequent decisions of the Union governments on this subject.

Mr Marinescu's work, to which we have expressed our support, deals with the specific cases of some countries which, at the time of their accession, assumed particular obligations in the field of the deactivation of nuclear installations and which received special support from the European Union for this activity.
Beyond the specific cases in this area, I will have to establish an effective verification and inspection control of the nuclear power stations in the Union.
In fact, the number of reactors which are expected to be decommissioned in the near future in Community territory seems to be high.

It will therefore be essential to ensure guarantee mechanisms, also and above all in these cases, for the allocation of adequate financial resources needed to meet both ordinary and extraordinary needs.
I would also like to thank the rapporteur.
The report takes account of the innovations in the changes in control and communication systems.
This also creates a framework of great interregionality, in particular on the part of the States in the communication of irregularities and fraud.

The report repeatedly points out the strangeness of the low levels of fraud and irregularities reported by different countries in relation to agricultural expenditure, structural funds and pre-accession funds.
It is really necessary to clarify the statistical data that have been provided.
The picture is then aggravated by the obvious result of the inefficiency of the recoveries.
However, one fact seems clear and confirms a long-standing trend.

The fight for legality and transparency in the spending of European resources, such as the fight against evasion and revenue avoidance, cannot yet rely on the full cooperation of States, governments and the European institutions.

In this respect, I think it is appropriate to make advanced requests for a revision of Community procurement legislation and the need to have what I call a European public register of beneficiaries of Community funds.
I would like to thank the rapporteurs and also Commissioner Barnier for his great availability to Parliament.
We support the idea of an internal market capable of understanding and meeting social expectations and the implications of the social dimension.
It's not a utopia, it's realism and also modernity.

It is this vision that makes the market itself stronger, because the only economic element, essentially the reduction of the market to economism, has shown that all this does not solve the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
It is, in short, a question of fully and presently realizing the all-European idea of a social market economy.
In today's texts, this is it.
There is the recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutual societies, foundations, 10 of European enterprises and much of our employment.
These are realities that are real companies, a demonstration of economic pluralism and corporate pluralism.

They work with capital, but not for capital, and they want to create jobs, welfare, quality and social innovation and to demonstrate that these values must and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

Mr President, does the justification of Beijing not convince you that the artist Ai Weiwei was arrested for economic crimes, does it not convince you that such harassment was exercised against a free and dissident artist?
It is not convincing, since such an arrest is part of hundreds of arrests of opponents and systematic repression of all dissent.

In the days when the Arab uprisings explode, our thoughts go to the image of cruel violence in Tiananmen Square against the young Chinese who asked, as they do today with the Gershom revolution, for freedom and democracy.
China is open to the West economically, but without combining production with respect for the environment and job security, and fails to have any openness to democracy and pluralism.

Ours is not an interference in Chinese internal affairs, as Beijing supports, but the appeal of men and women, of movements, of parties, who intend to build a world free of intolerance on every continent.
The Beijing government is watching what is happening in the world to understand that if it does not change, it will be the events of history and the Chinese citizens who will change China.
Mr President, jobs have been lost in the face of several million euros invested in support policies.

This is a disastrous budget in terms of the impact on SMEs of the triumphant Lisbon I project and the Europe 2020 photocopy strategy, on which it is even being decided to concentrate the resources of the next multiannual financial framework 2014

I cannot but reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are wondering: what is the use of Europe if it is unable to solve the economic problems of the continent and cannot speak with one voice on foreign policy and money?
I hope that what Commissioner Tajani has said many times will come true.
I hope that the revision of the SME code will really be able to simplify bureaucracy, ensure access to and recovery of credit, and facilitate the Internet of Things.
The directive on late payment has achieved a concrete and real goal, but it is the result of political will and not of European propaganda.

If the costs of the next strategy will still only fund chatter, I call on the European institutions to make amends to the dozens of small entrepreneurs who, in my region of Veneto, took their own lives before their small business failed.

Madam President, while Europe is pretending to be nothing, the 2011 Europol report on organised crime argues that with the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen, the powerful Turkish, Russian and Albanian criminal organisations will be able to expand their activities throughout Europe.
Again, I quote textually, Turkey's illegal immigration will expand to the coasts of Bulgaria, increasing the trafficking of drugs and human beings into the hands of Albanian Turkish crime.

Again, on human trafficking, the entry into Schengen of Romania and Bulgaria could give Bulgarian crime and the new Roma communities new opportunities to increase their already substantial trafficking towards the rest of Europe.
In short, there is an increase in illegal immigration from Turkey and drug and human trafficking, less security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do a great favor to organized crime.
The Lega Nord party is and will always be against this kind of bad choices.
Whoever votes in favour of this report tomorrow will be responsible for a vote which will open up organised crime to a highway that leads straight to the neck of Europe.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the Treaty of Amsterdam, environmental policy and sustainability policy have become more relevant and the European Union has become more relevant.
Attention has been focused on the integration of economic and environmental policy and the inclusion of environmental issues in policies and other sectors.

Key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, invited the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the fundamental aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be complemented by integrated economic and environmental accounting suitable for providing fully coherent data.
I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because it creates new uses for national accounting data and for environmental statistics and other statistical sectors.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my vote in favour of the Garriga report on the Union's forthcoming financial prospects stems from the conviction that it is precisely in one of the moments of greatest crisis that we are facing a crisis.
The European spirit is decisive in insisting on and winning over the necessity of providing credible instruments, starting with adequate financial endowment for the Union.
Therefore, the request for an additional 5 for the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not enough, but indispensable to give answers to the big questions before us.
We need to be able to tackle real problems, such as stronger cohesion between regions, greater capacity for research and innovation, stronger capacity to generate growth and to offer employment.

If adequate measures are taken, none of these problems will be sufficiently addressed, starting with the introduction of this intermediate category in cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not harm other existing categories.
That is why I voted in favour and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the guidelines of this report.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the new Hungarian Constitution reduces the possibility of intervention by control bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive, thus calling into question the normal balance of power.
Social rights are abolished, the State provides subsidies to the needy only if they agree to carry out public works.
Finally, the right to self-defence, which allows the possession of weapons at home even without a license, is sanctioned.
The right to abortion is prohibited and strictly discriminatory rules are introduced against homosexuals.
All this is contrary to Directive No 78 which establishes a general framework for the fight against discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to act, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are hardly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are about to vote on a very important strategic document which offers the negotiations on the financial prospects for the post-2013 period a solid reference framework.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy has adopted a number of amendments to the Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens.
This coherence also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation that arises from public opinion, from the beneficiaries of EU policies, from the European social and productive forces.
We have done it for cohesion, a crucial chapter in deciding what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
It is said that cohesion is today a vital link in the European project, an important heritage for all to safeguard, to protect, to renew.

I particularly criticize the efforts made on this front on the hypothesis of introducing an intermediate category of regions, especially because in several cases the years of recession that we have behind us have had a negative impact on the European economy.
We have bridged the internal gaps, making even more important efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe, combating waste and setting out clearly the development policy.
And yet I believe that the challenge of the intermediate categories, with the safeguard clause, is a challenge we must accept in order to open a new phase in European policy.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
I too would like to thank Mr Langen and the other colleagues with whom we have worked to put this complex report together.
I think it is particularly important what you have mentioned.
Mr Langen when he said that we want to maintain the scope, the scope of this regulation, keeping faith with what was the mandate of the G20 in Pittsburgh in 2009.
The fundamental objective is to bring back most of the derivatives on regulated platforms to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of
When you get to, as it happened, trading and securing $400 million without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, you understand what the risks are that we are running.

Having said that, however, I would also like to point out two problems. The first is the relationship with the Council. The second problem is the organic nature of the proposal for reform of the financial markets which we must take forward.

I raise the first problem with regard to the Council, and I say this very clearly: the feeling is too often that the Council is an obstacle to doing well and soon in the reform of the financial markets.
I hope that the new presidency will take up this problem, because even on this occasion we must put the
I am aware of an extension of time which is largely due to the positions, difficulties and contradictions which arise in the Council.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we want to follow.
The second issue is the organicity and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the provision on OTCs, there is the provision on short selling and so on.

I would like to draw attention to two points: the specific issue of the raw materials market, a particular market which requires specific anti-speculative measures, and the problem of the derivative exposure of local autonomies in the countries of the European Union.
I think these are problems on which Parliament must intervene.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Fukushima accident continues to have very serious consequences, with the loss of radioactive water at sea exceeding legal limits by 6 times.
The risk of food contamination is high.
Europe has imposed very strict controls, but this applies exclusively to fresh products.
No protection rules have been issued for processed products, in particular for fish in containers.
We import 370 tonnes of tuna in a box, and the main suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that the fish in a box imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is essential and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently recognised this and intends to fill this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which will not enter into force for two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not enter into force for three years.
We must not create alarms, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must act as soon as possible.
Mr President, Mr Tusk, your speech gives us good hope, the hope is that the Polish presidency will be a contribution to the battle against the Europe of selfishness.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy has adopted a number of amendments to the Commission's proposal.
But as you rightly said in your speech, a presidency has concrete problems to face and to solve.
In this short time, I would like to point out two crucial issues on the front of the economic and financial crisis.
The first issue is the reform of financial markets.
It is not a technical problem, it is a great democratic issue of our time.
Secondly, we are dealing with the issue of taxation of financial transactions, we must get to the bottom of this, we expect the Polish Presidency to make a concrete contribution in this respect.
It has been more than 20 years since the signing of the Schengen agreements.
No one doubts the advantages of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current system is no longer adequate to current and future needs.

That is why the Member States of the EU as a whole must commit themselves to reviewing the mechanisms for the functioning of Schengen, so that freedom of movement does not go at the expense of the just security needs of our citizens.

As far as we know, the Commission's guidelines can also be partly shared, especially with regard to the introduction of a mechanism allowing States to temporarily suspend border controls in the event of an emergency.
However, it remains to be seen how this will be done and whether the statements will be followed by facts and, above all, by concrete results.

It will certainly also be necessary to undertake a general reform of the European border protection system, especially the external ones, on which Frontex must become as soon as possible an agency with real powers of intervention and support for national authorities.
We must protect our external borders if we are to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if we do not just want to survive.

The crisis has deeply affected the real lives of European citizens and businesses and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering the social and cultural quality, well-being and future of young people and Europeans.

To get out of the crisis means to create remedies for the causes identified, remedies against speculation, which, if necessary, must also be curbed by imposing strict rules on financial markets, remedies that must be applied in a balanced way.
