Remedies against the recession, remedies against an unbalanced development model that has put the person a step below the profit, remedies against the rising nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that are competing with it today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, the resources, even new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, with research, innovation, training, support for productive investment, infrastructure and work, because without work people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Pervaiz Bers and his colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a proud and aware Europe.
If there are, it is now the responsibility of the European leadership to implement them.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, behind the widespread prosperity of our continent there is a hidden, often invisible Europe which we speak of as numbers, statistics and sociology and not as people in the flesh, often women and children or the elderly, that is, the most fragile population.
But Europe will not be credible to the citizens if it does not learn to be coherent, and we here want to be coherent in this Parliament, in this phase of European life.

And so, if we say that we are going to build the Union on values, on human rights, I do not think we can interrupt or cut so drastically a programme for those who do not eat, for those who do not have the right to food, to access to food.

It is an agricultural fund, it is a social fund and, if it is to be social, Madam Commissioner, it must not be at the expense of other social programmes, but a new ad hoc fund with appropriate resources.
We say we want to guarantee food security for Europeans, but the first right to security is to have it, the food that is then healthy.
So here is our consistency and our commitment.

Let us therefore find a legal solution that gives continuity and that, with the help of non-governmental organisations and volunteering, guarantees the first fundamental human right, that of the citizen.
I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is prepared to accept the amendments tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
This phase of regionalisation has a particular application in the Black Sea.
I believe that the elements contained in Mrs Iotova's report describe a particular situation, but one that can be repeated in the rest of Europe.
In other words, the interactions, especially between European fishing and extra-European fishing, are often very harmful to European markets and European consumers.
The second issue I would like to highlight quickly is the call for a common coastguard.
There is no politics if there is no exercise of control.

I believe that the time has come to understand how one of the first forces of the European order, the coastguards, can have a common management, a greater correlation and, why not, a single European body.
With this in mind, I fully support the contents of Mrs Iotova's report.
Mr President, the disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico more than a year ago has prompted the European Commission to reflect on legislation relating to the operation of offshore oil platforms.
The European Parliament also wanted to express its position on this matter with this report, by approving a text which requires adequate technical and financial capabilities.
It aims to set high safety standards to strengthen the European Union's leading role in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new interventions in the areas requested by the Commission will have to focus on international coordination and a realistic approach combining all the existing excellence.
In the sector, at the level of procedures, and avoid the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy, which would risk distancing from the achievement of concrete final objectives.

The report, in particular, in addition to increasing the accountability of the operating companies, calls for the improvement of the mechanisms for communication and sharing of information and knowledge and aims to strengthen and expand the role of the European Maritime Safety Agency.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved to be positive, thanks to the negotiations on this text, to which we have expressed our support.
I would like to thank my colleagues Mr Seeber and Mr Schillacaquis, and I would also like to thank Commissioner Heidegger.

I believe that we are here today discussing and reasoning to really try to achieve a strong European climate policy capable of safeguarding the economic development and well-being of European citizens.
In the past, international climate policies, as has been pointed out so far, have focused mainly on reducing CO2 emissions.
This proposal highlights how we must also tackle the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, affecting climate change.

There are already a lot of things that have been mentioned that I think it is right to keep in mind, and we are able to do that today at absolutely reasonable costs, we have the technologies at our disposal, and no matter how much doubt there is that it is CO2 emissions that are the main cause of this.

Although it is doubtful that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are in a much more limited proportion, it is doubtful that their potential is very high and that we will be able to achieve significant results in a few years.
These are important points.
I have seen a study published on Nature by the Scientific Agency of the American Department of Commerce, with which I find that the European Union is in a very difficult situation.

There are many points of contact with the analysis made by my colleagues, and I therefore imagine that these may also be the things that will allow Europe to present itself in Durban with an even stronger, more concrete and important position.

I just want to remind you, as has already been reminded, that in the extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment in which we are living, we talked about the homeless until a few minutes ago, there is a sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account, and therefore consider that the great

With our sensitivity, of course, to jobs first, we should also be able to carry out a communication campaign that explains well to citizens what we really want to do in the direction of development and their well-being and the protection of jobs.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the single market, free movement and the Treaty of Lisbon are all elements which have intervened without changing our way of legislating, the European way and the national way.

If we are to follow up the commitments derived from these occasions, we must in particular really start a phase of simplification of the legislative system, a phase of simplification which must produce a different dialogue between Europe and the individual States.
I would like to take this opportunity to suggest a kind of test of clarity on our documents. When we make a white paper, a green paper, everything must be more understandable.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is prepared to accept the amendments tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Representative of the Council and Commissioner, first of all I too would like to welcome positively, as have other colleagues, the anti-corruption package which the European Commission adopted on 6 June.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures of European scope are needed to combat it.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe must do more.
How can we blame them?

Many Member States have lacked the political will to combat corruption, and it is enough to think that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we think of the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, on citizens' rights and on trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures of countermeasures adopted so far by the Member States are insufficient to contain an expanding phenomenon.

It is the European Union that must give a united and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis that is weighing on people's lives, on the maintenance of welfare systems, on the capacity of institutions to provide essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of EUR 120 billion every year, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily robs the Union and the Member States of resources.
They could be used to provide basic services such as education, childcare, employment, transport, and to extract clean resources from people's support.
We must therefore have more courage and more firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by intensifying and tightening anti-corruption measures at Union level.

In particular, we cannot talk about the fight against corruption if we are not able to adopt, at least, minimum standards for the definition of the crime of corruption, which is not reflected in the package just discussed.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in the Member States, which is essential to provide an effective response.
We are in favour, for example, of relaunching the EU's network of anti-corruption contact points, as proposed in the resolution we will be voting on tomorrow.
The crisis is not of yesterday, it has existed for some years.
Perhaps it is time to make a critical assessment of the policies pursued so far.
We have always made appropriate analyses of the situation.
Did you choose the right approach?
The European Central Bank itself, which, as Minister Rostovsky says, has saved Europe, has always done well, even when, fearing inflation, it has raised interest rates?
President Barroso identifies a problem the speed of the markets and the slowness of the policy, but is this the only problem?

Of course, if you think that we are still at the implementation of 21 July, this should at least suggest that we prepare and organise the summits and their conclusions better, but the policy will be slower and slower than the markets.
So the point is to look further, to shift the emphasis to the fight against unemployment and development.

This is the ground on which the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more concrete talk about the deficit and less about the indications of growth and development.

The Commission goes beyond its weakness, saying that the priority is the fight against unemployment and job creation, the redistribution of wealth and a strategy of public investment, also changing those which are the rules of the new European Stability Pact.
Mr President, I believe that the challenge of the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, retains the primacy of first and foremost.
It is a world-class tourist destination and at the same time capable of enhancing both its environmental protection and its competitive capacity throughout its territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and unexpected challenge, not only in view of the opportunities but also in view of the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector and on other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani recalled, it is becoming fundamental, as also highlighted in the Commission's opinion, which we approved in the Committee on Regional Development.
to combine a strong overall strategy for the European Union as a whole on tourism with a strengthening of the role of regions and territories.
In this respect, full involvement from the outset in respecting the principle of subsidiarity of regions and local authorities is essential.
In addition, I believe that the development of integrated tourism networks and projects, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of good practices, should be encouraged.
I also think it is right to propose the identification of a Europe brand that can define a high quality of the tourist product.

Of course, it will be up to the Commission to define the priorities better, especially also from the financial point of view, in order to ensure that this primacy of Europe is maintained in the future.

Madam President, the preparation of the common strategic framework for the financing of research and innovation is one of the greatest opportunities facing European development and the European economy.

It is a question of acting on the lever that can really start a moment of growth and also of a new skilled occupation, such as that of researchers and young people who are dedicated to new opportunities for innovation, technology and related professions.
One remark, above all, arises from this work, namely that we must increasingly emphasize research and innovation in Europe that reaches practical application.

We need to create new enterprises, which will receive new patents and which will not be left with pure basic research and pure knowledge, which is important but not enough to really spark the flame of development.

The second observation is the relationship with local authorities, regions and territories, which are also an important instrument for programming on the ground and for the encounter between research, universities, centres of excellence and enterprises.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, European schools were created with the aim of ensuring access to education in their mother tongue to the children of European agents and institutions called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was created in Luxembourg in 1953 on the initiative of a group of civil servants.
Over the years, considering the positivity of this form of teaching, as many as 14 European schools have been created in the various Member States.

While recognising that the European school system is more of a necessity than a luxury, it is clear that, more than 50 years after the creation of the first European school, this system may have outdated aspects and must somehow be adapted to the new economic and social needs of the European Union.

I therefore voted in favour of Mr Cavada's text, which calls for greater involvement of the European Union in supporting and coordinating the actions of the Member States called upon to work to develop and improve the European school system.
We know that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent decades there has been an exponential increase in the number of natural disasters that have killed tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, as a member of the Committee on Development, I followed the work of the report on the European Union's capacity to respond to disasters.
How much more needs to be done to ensure a coordinated response by the European Union to the proliferation of earthquakes, floods and tsunamis?
The European Union's response to the earthquake in Haiti, for example, has clearly shown the complexity of the existing instruments and procedures.

Although the Member States and the EU institutions acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis has raised a number of problems in terms of efficiency, coordination and transparency.
That is why I voted in favour of Mrs Elisabetta Gardini's text, which calls for greater efficiency in all phases of disaster management, greater coordination and better management of disasters.
It is also important to ensure that the Commission's proposals are implemented in a timely manner and that they are implemented in a timely manner.
It is only a good initiative, and I believe that it will be about building a European policy on tourism.
The European brand is a good intuition, but on two issues I want to emphasize there is no sea or coastal tourism without a coastal planning policy.

I believe that the time has come for Europe, precisely to protect this important sector, to produce an initiative in which the design of the sea and the design of the coasts is not limited to a kind of urban planning that ends up on the dry land and does not involve the sea as a whole.
I believe that an integrated policy in this respect is useful, as well as building everything that is behind the claims of rural tourism.

It is an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for areas where there is no more work, where it is important, on the other hand, that the depopulation does not continue and that there is human settlement.
Well, there it is not enough to make statements, but we should suggest to Europe and to the individual states to intervene on the tax levy.
I would like to express my congratulations on the work done by Mr Fidanza, who is logically placed in the framework of the actions of the European Union.
The European Union has been actively engaged and promoted at Community level in the field of tourism since the Treaty of Lisbon gave the EU new competences in this field.
I share and want to emphasize the importance of a Europe as a single destination for certified and quality tourism and the desire to promote this.

The same idea, translating it into actions at the level of structures, allocation of resources, financing, coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the countries of the Union.
A valuable and rewarding approach given the sector in question, with its returns in terms of GDP, employment, new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.

The Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the protection of the environment is designed to develop and thus to respond to the main challenges posed by the present.
For all these reasons, I consider this report to be positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European tourism policy.
Mr President, also for the recovery, three small considerations.
I believe that it is inevitable that in some areas there should really be an attitude in which not only is Europe hoped for, but more Europe is being built.
More Europe means, for example, starting to really think about common road police, identical rules in terms of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European policy on training, not simply delegating it to individual States, but building, for example, a genuine policy on training.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
More Europe means having common tools inside the machines to improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol and anti-drug tools.
I believe that they are a point strategy to be built with the car companies and with the European production of motor vehicles.
I believe that if all this falls within the framework of the conviction of a common policy, I really think that perhaps conditions will improve.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report deals with a subject which is global food security.

It draws some lines, such as the essential one, of coherence between European policies and this objective of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well but is often not coherent in its choices.
I just want to trace, however, the titles of three innovative lines which I think we should develop further.
The first is that the supply of food today is at risk from price volatility due to speculation on food products, which must be contained if not prevented, derivatives, etc.
Secondly, the issue of land grabbing, which I think must be the subject of some form of treaty or negotiation, because democracy is at risk, as well as the survival of many peoples.
Thirdly, consistency between supply and energy policies.
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent food from being produced for the peoples of the world.
Mr President, I voted in favour of Mr Zimmer's report, first of all for a political reason.
It is purely political, because I think it is necessary to bring this great issue of food security back to the centre of the initiative of the whole of the European Union.

It is not just a question of helping developing countries to deal more effectively with this issue, but the food crisis, since it is expected that by 2050 the demand for food will increase by more than 70%.

It is a big issue that, if not tackled in time and with determination, will become one of the main threats, if not the most important threat, to stability, peace and also to democracy, as has been seen.

That is why I believe that it is essential that the whole of the European Union, together with the Member States, make every effort, starting with adequate economic investment, as indicated in the report, in this direction, to tackle this major issue seriously.
I must really thank all the people who have contributed in these weeks, in these months, to the production of this document which we are voting on in this House today.
We have worked, I must say very well, and a really constructive debate has developed.
The motion for a resolution which we are voting on today is therefore the result of a really common work and the result of the contribution of all the political forces and of the whole Parliament.

I think there has been a very strong common awareness of this issue, also because we have to remember that we are living in an era that is really characterized by an exponential increase in disasters.
The numbers, if we look at them in their crude form, are very eloquent, the number of disasters in the world has quintupled, if we think that in 1975
Seventy-eight catastrophic events had been recorded, while today we have almost 400 disastrous events a year.

Mr President, in the last 20 years, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have been 90,000 and more than 29 million individuals have been affected by the disasters, while the economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is clear that we are faced with phenomena of such a magnitude that require a stronger response, a more effective response and a really strong commitment on our part.
We all have in our eyes the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, what happened in Japan.
Mr President, Europe itself sees sudden floods, fires and, let us remember, the cloud of ash following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano on its territory every year.
There is no need to go any further to state how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
The principle of solidarity, which is reinforced by the solidarity clause of the Treaty of Lisbon, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We're moving along these lines.

Madam President, the European Union's intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as evidenced by the work of our Commissioner Georgieva, but today we need to make a qualitative leap.
A leap in quality that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to a response where the reaction
be enhanced through the preventive identification of the means available in the Member States under the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is also important to emphasise this leap in quality, from information sharing and emergency response to the role of planning and monitoring.
I would like to take this opportunity to express my concern about what is happening with regard to the budget, with regard to these new technologies, which are fundamental.
We have inserted the importance of communication to the citizens, because this too has been taught to us a lot by Japanese experience and it is never enough, it is never enough.
And we expect the Commission, which we ask to present as soon as possible the proposal on civil protection in legislative form.
Mr President, oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to live in secret of their faith, priests brutally killed without the authorities moving a finger.
My party, the Northern League, has always been opposed to Turkey's entry into Europe because it represents a potential Trojan horse of radical Islamism on our continent.
Today more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must put an end to the accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has made to Europe must be met with an immediate response.
We cannot accept a third country telling Europe what to do.
Cyprus is a full member of the EU and has the undisputed right to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must give a precise signal and show itself ready to defend Cyprus by any means necessary in the face of Turkey's arrogance and political and military preponderance.
Let us immediately suspend the accession negotiations and also be ready to suspend trade relations.
We are experiencing a decisive step towards the future of the euro and, with it, the whole of European construction.
To have this awareness would mean to get out of a short-sighted logic which subordinates everything to an ideological will to strictly balance the accounts.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order, we all want to reduce the debt.
However, it is clear that without a smart investment policy capable of breathing new life into the economy, there will be no chance of growth.
The only clear result of this approach is that the heaviest prices, as always, will be paid by the weakest cents.
That is why, together with the Socialist and Democratic Group, we voted against this report.
In fact, it is moving in a single direction, that of rigorous growth, a direction which has so far been shown to be wrong.
I very much appreciate the work that Mrs Ferrara has done on this report.
In fact, on the package of six legislative proposals on economic governance, only on this did my group and I vote in favour.

We have done so because, among other things, a social rights protection clause has been inserted, starting with collective bargaining, and there is also a strengthening of Parliament's role in the adoption of delegated acts.

So, although it is not possible to change the overall balance of the six-proposal package, this report certainly takes a step forward in having, among other things, a system of surveillance that takes account of fundamental rights.

And so, in this context, I would like to say that a vision, in our view, based solely on an austerity policy does not produce positive results, and this report certainly constitutes a positive note in contrast.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Finland and the Netherlands have taken up their seats in the Council for a very simple reason: Bulgaria and Romania are unable to guarantee effective border controls today and are three acts of unbridled corruption involving the political class and organised crime.
In this way, it is not the populist parties and movements that are thinking, but Europol in its 2010 report on organised crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security problem.

If Bulgaria were to enter the Schengen area at this time, police and security agencies predict that the Bulgarian borders, especially the maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become crossroads for human trafficking and drugs.

It is natural that some Member States have many reservations about the real ability of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls against organised crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they have opposed their accession to Schengen.
To allow it now means to open the way to transnational crime and to open a gap in European borders, precisely where there is a very strong migratory pressure from Turkey.
The reasons for opposing it are many, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore ask you to know what the Commission and the Council intend to do on this delicate issue, which I believe has been dealt with so far with great care.

It is not sufficient and does not take into account the dangers posed by the entry of Bulgaria and Romania, at the behest of the competent authorities in the field of security and international crime.

In my view, the Commission and the Council should postpone the accession of these two countries to Schengen and give the OK only when there is a reasonable certainty that the accession of Bulgaria and Romania will not have a detrimental impact on the security of European citizens.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the crisis in Europe is weaving the problems of public budgets and private capital into a vicious circle with those of the productivity of our enterprises, and the spectre of recession is there.
So if the priority of SMEs is crucial, I ask the Commission to work absolutely, together with Parliament, to ensure that our good principles are put into practice.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament.

If you think about it, Commissioner, what would not happen if all the Member States were to advance the application of the directive against payment delays, what would be the great advantage for SMEs?

It is certainly right to check whether when we legislate we really do so in the interests and to the extent of small and mediumsized enterprises, but we ask that you proceed with great constancy and tenacity, say in depth, in creating this framework of opportunities that you have traced.
We appreciate what is being done, including by the Commission, and we are ready with the budget and the other possibilities we have to support it.
I'm just saying a word about credit.
Let's have a clear conversation with the banks, I tell you, Commissioner, because we have to help small and medium-sized enterprises.
Mr President, I voted in favour of the text tabled by Mr Wallis.
While not prejudicing the usual ways of accessing justice, I am convinced that an alternative solution to the ADR dispute represents a quick and economical alternative to legal disputes.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, the DR can also have a significant development online for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through joint action with the Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonised legal framework which, by strengthening citizens' confidence in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

The report on the provisions for the sectors placed on the market in the flexibility regime, for which we voted in favour, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach which has been adopted by the Commission.

On the one hand, by avoiding the imposition of unlikely and impossible requirements, and on the other by providing for a so-called flexibility regime, which is articulated in the forecast of temporary phases and corresponding quantitative limits of the budget.

It provides for the placing on the market of an annual pre-established quota of tractors corresponding to certain characteristics and thus allows the adaptation to the pre-established standards to be diluted in time without hindrance for the productive and industrial sectors concerned.

Mr Tatarella, the work you have done has been important and has ensured that there is a careful balance between the needs dictated by the major challenges facing the European Union at this time and those of protecting the environment and the current context of the economic crisis.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current global economic crisis, even worse than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade disparities between countries, financial markets lacking common rules, the instability of banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, which I support, urgently calls for a total reform, new rules and global economic coordination.

The economy needs a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, a more responsible monetary policy and stricter supervision policies, and decision-making bodies and international economic bodies must be the main actors at the heart of this new approach.

Europe, in particular, needs a more transparent approach to reduce the instability exacerbated by globalisation and to ensure wide-ranging reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment and this resolution emphasizes it to all countries.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of Mrs Mattera's report, which analyses the situation of single mothers, who today represent, as has already been said, more than 5% of the population of the European Union.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text adopted today supports those policies which can provide concrete help for these women, such as, for example, the facilitation of women's participation in the labour market.
health care, flexible working conditions that allow for the reconciliation of private and professional life, priority access to housing at affordable prices and special unemployment benefits.
Only by adopting these measures can the needs of an increasingly significant category be met in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Mr President, the budget sets out a few clear and important objectives in the context of the EU 2020 strategy, for which I thank the rapporteurs.
It is essential to focus on investment and not just on the prudent maintenance of the budget.
The alternative would be to passively attend to the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to follow individual interests, but we must finally represent a single, compact and ready-to-confront subject.

I welcome the commitments made to pilot projects and preparatory actions in heading 2, so that the financing of the integrated maritime policy does not go at the expense of other fisheries sector initiatives and programmes.

This will allow us to implement new policies towards better management of marine resources through research and the exchange of capillary data on marine stocks, imposing new designs that in the Adriatic area can be used as best practices in other marine areas.

I conclude with a small note in the context of future debates on the ECB and in particular on the Fisheries Fund, I hope that greater efforts will be made to control fishing, which is at the heart of the fight against illegal fishing but also a basis for the reconstruction of the stocks.
I think it's important that we consider fish a common good.
Mr President, the economic, financial and social crisis we are going through has clearly highlighted several weaknesses in the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most alarming and representative figures of the current situation is the almost six million jobs lost in the last three years, figures which, as a result of this situation, are destined to grow if we do not react promptly and effectively.

The text by Mrs Bastos stresses that, in order to take concrete steps forward, better synergy between education, training and the labour market is needed, with policies to ensure greater responsiveness between demand and supply in that market.
For these reasons, Mr President, I voted in favour.
I voted in favour of what Mr Angelilli has presented because I am dealing with a problem which, as a mother and as a grandmother, deeply interests me.
Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse and the disgusting world of child pornography means defending our children, our grandchildren, and consequently defending the weakest.
greater prevention, tougher criminal action against those who commit such crimes and more careful protection of children, on these key points of the document voted today.
Without a doubt, the path is difficult.
I am thinking in particular of the dissemination of child pornography on the Internet, which can only be combated with close cooperation between the Member States, police authorities and providers.
The challenges posed by modernity and the report by Mrs Renata Fidin, for which we voted in favour, require that the citizen be put in his consumer's clothes at the same time.

They are at the heart of the Community debate and remind us that the protection of its interests cannot remain just a principle enshrined in the Treaty, but must be a concrete guiding principle of the policies of the European Union.

A protected and informed consumer, made more aware and therefore able to make full use of the instruments and resources at his disposal, able to fully enjoy his rights, must be the ultimate objective of the new European Union strategy for consumer policy.

This strategy must therefore be set up as a comprehensive approach, ranging from the financial services sector to the food sector, child protection and advertising, and thus be able to make an important contribution to Europe's social and environmental objectives.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the online gambling sector is constantly expanding, with a turnover of several billion euros and many problematic issues to be solved.

I therefore fully agree with the adoption of all those measures which are aimed at safeguarding the integrity of sport, including through greater coordination between the Member States and the various sports federations.
Last year, together with Mr Iacolino, we presented an inquiry calling for decisive action by the EU institutions to prevent fraud involving rigged sporting events.

It is necessary to counteract the possible interference of organised crime in European sport, by asking, as in the text voted today, for a common definition of sporting fraud and for the harmonisation of sanctions at European level.
I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report, and I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report.

Mr President, this and the next few years are crucial for the future and for the unity of Europe, and we must not forget that the European Union is the only continent on the planet that is not at war with itself.

The work programme must therefore be more fully integrated into this logic of extraordinariness, which means, of course, concentrating activities on the essential objectives, giving more concrete effect to our action, concentrating investments on those forms which can in turn put them into practice.

But also, as the honourable Member said, to see the Commission, Mr President Barroso, if I may have your attention for a moment, to see the Commission play a more active and more direct role in the reality of some countries and of the euro area and of Europe as a whole.

The Commission and Europe are able to do this in a concrete way.

At a time when Horizon 2020 is going to be one of the main topics, we need to do a lot of research on innovation for businesses, big and small.
The chapter on the digital agenda, which is also very important, because the creation of this single market will be a great help for society.

The policies of combating new and old poverty, which are unfortunately increasing in Europe today, in the Europe of the crisis of recent years, and also of austerity policies, in a single sense, especially by the States, are not enough.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so what is the Commission's position?
And above all on the individual States, we should use the European Semester to monitor, year after year, concretely the policies that the individual States are devoting to this fundamental challenge.

In order to make credible the objective of reducing poverty and social exclusion for some 20 million European citizens, it is therefore necessary to have consistency between the vast resources that Europe must make available, the States must make available, and the concrete policies that we can put in place.
It is estimated that it will take about two billion euros from now until 2020 to achieve, say, the objectives we are proposing.

This is the challenge we are highlighting and putting at the centre of attention as the Committee on Budgets, coherence between the financial resources we make available and the policies we put in place.
Madam President, poverty is a problem in our countries, the elderly, women, young people, the disabled and millions of people and families on their knees from the crisis and speculation.
In the face of this situation, we are here to discuss plans to support the Roma community, to provide accommodation and to give to immigrants.
We must think about helping the really disadvantaged and also give financial and political support to the family, which is the institution on which our society is founded.
We must help small and medium-sized enterprises stricken by the crisis, because these SMEs are the real antidote to poverty and the real source of wealth in our countries.
We must give priority to our best forces, not tax them to guarantee migrants a minimum wage that Europe wants to take away from the rest.
Enough talk about the Roma and the migrants, now we must give priority to the real excluded.
If we look around, we'll see a lot of them, and you don't have to go into a Roma camp to see them.
To these excluded Europe must direct its efforts and its funds, now more than ever.

Mr President, I voted in favour of the text on the work of the ACP Joint Committee, which, thanks to the quality of the work done, has established itself as a key actor in cooperation between the North and the South of the world.
I myself, as a member of that Assembly, participated in the meetings held in Brussels and in the work carried out in Tenerife in April 2010 and in Kinshasa, Congo, in December of the same year.

It is precisely thanks to these visits that I have been able to touch, as I did in Angola in 2009, the sad conditions experienced daily by certain peoples and at the same time to assess the efforts made by the ACP to improve things.

In conclusion, I would like to emphasize, at a particular historical and political moment, especially for the countries of North Africa and the Middle East, how the role played by the ACP has been important.

This is of fundamental importance, especially in the context of the supervision of the negotiations on the Economic Partnership Agreements, favouring the transparency of such processes and the development of the desired local realities.
Mr President, I personally find it interesting that a brand of European heritage is being established in the European Union.

At a time when, because of the persistent economic crisis, a certain Euroscepticism is spreading in many Member States, he believes that an initiative of this kind can strengthen the sense of belonging of European citizens to the Union.

The characteristic element of the European brand is not the beauty of a site, but the symbolic value it has represented or represents for the integration of European citizens on the path to better inter-cultural dialogue.
Mr President, in December 2009 I attended the COP15 in Copenhagen as an official member of the European Parliament delegation.

It has been about two years and, with regret, I can say that the work done and the commitments made in Copenhagen, then formalized in Cancun, will not be enough to achieve the objective of limiting to 2 degrees Celsius the increase in the average annual temperature on our planet.
Some of the major emitters, such as Japan or Russia, seem to want to break away from their commitments, while others seem not to give the right priority to the problem of climate change.

Today, while I am examining and expressing my vote in favour, I am aware that only with the great and firm will of the Heads of State and Government of the world can we create the conditions for a complete international agreement.
Internet-related services still have many potential, both for the economy and for a more inclusive and participatory society.
Today, in the transposition phase of the telecom package into national legislation, there is a risk of fragmentation of the European framework.

The priorities we want to reiterate in this debate are guaranteeing network neutrality, developing broadband infrastructure and developing more open software, security of access and interoperability of systems, promoting the use of

the development of digital technologies in the various industrial and service sectors, the production of digital content and new services, the inclusion of people who are excluded today, I mean the disabled, but not only, the defence of information and cultural pluralism.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all know how important the role of the International Criminal Court is in prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times the Court has increasingly been the subject of unjust attacks of a political nature.
His arrest warrants have often been ignored and therefore the current budget is not proportionate to the efforts and commitment made.

I therefore voted in favour of the text adopted today because it is the task of the European Union to carry out all political, diplomatic and logistical actions to support the Court and ensure its independence and correct and effective functioning.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the phosphates in household washing detergents end up in water systems, in rivers, streams and European lakes.

Phosphorus accelerates the reproduction of various life forms, and as a result, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment.
This excessive growth of algae takes oxygen away from other living organisms and can also produce toxins by destroying plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore voted in favour of the text voted today because, in order to purify Europe's water heritage, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is spilled in the waters of our continent.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the text presented by Mr Lisek analyses the possible measures to be taken to reduce defence costs in a period of financial crisis, which are heavily burdening the Community budget.
The main proposals concern better coordination of the planning of the defence system, the sharing and sharing of defence capabilities, support for research and technological development.
I therefore agree with the rapporteur's position that the economic and financial crisis which has hit us can be an opportunity for the integration of the European Union.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing the European Union's defence policies, and whether he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing the European Union's defence policies.
For these reasons, I voted in favour.
Mr President, the Arab Spring and the resulting revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy have made it necessary to review the European neighbourhood policy.

It is clear that, as things stand, relations with the countries concerned must be more focused on cooperation in order to ensure the priority of democracy and security on both sides of the Mediterranean.

In this respect, I believe that intercultural and interreligious dialogue is essential to strengthen mutual respect and tolerance with the neighbouring partner countries, while at the same time promoting the fight against terrorism and extremism.
For these reasons, Mr President, I naturally voted in favour.
Mr President, yesterday in Florence an extremely serious incident occurred which is causing horror and dismay.
A 50-year-old man armed with a gun opened fire in two markets in the city of Florence on five citizens of Senegalese origin, two of them died and three are now hospitalized in serious condition.
The murderer then committed suicide.
He is a far-right, xenophobic racist who wanted to kill people he didn't know, guilty only of having black skin.
Florence is my city and before I was elected to the European Parliament I was mayor of Florence for ten years.
Florence is a civil and democratic city, gold medal for resistance to Nazi fascism.

Yet it was in Florence that this abominable racist crime took place, as a demonstration of the fact that Nazi-fascist madness can manifest itself anywhere and should never be thought to have been definitively erased.
Mr President, I ask you to express the European Parliament's condolences and to reiterate its commitment against all forms of racism and for the respect and rights of every human being.
Mr President, the management of projects in war zones such as Afghanistan is not directly comparable to the management implemented in the countries of the region.

However, it is necessary to try to understand why the gaps highlighted, the management of projects and the relevant risk factors, in order to improve the situation as much as possible.
I share the rapporteur's position in this respect, which calls on the Commission to take a closer look at fraud, corruption and non-compliance with the effectiveness of specific projects.
It is therefore necessary to increase transparency and accountability in the use of Union funds and to help both Member States and other donors to avoid making common mistakes.

The old approach, which no longer reflected the real geopolitical situation in the world, has just been overcome.
We continued to work on a photograph of the world of the 1990s, a photograph that is a long time old, if we look at it in perspective, projected towards 2050, it is really unsustainable.
We see that by 2050, among the top 30 economies in the world, there should be 19 countries that are currently still on the list of developing countries.
I believe that this change of pace is perhaps the most interesting fact from a political point of view and has in fact been pointed out also by our colleague Florenz on a point-by-point basis.
I also think that we should no longer proceed to tanks.

And then, recalling also what Mario Draghi, the governor of the European Central Bank, said the other day in this very institution, if we want to push, also in this sector, towards those who are the priorities.

For growth and employment, we really need to be concrete and focus above all on green economy technologies, to really deliver sustainable development and to meet the most important needs of our citizens.

Mr President, Europe is going downhill, the stock exchanges are collapsing, the centralistic Europe of the financial lobbies is collapsing, but the Danish Presidency is opening its semester by promising total fidelity to the Commission's plans to create a supergovernment of the continent.
Instead of focusing on measures to save the lives of 500 million citizens, the Danish government promises to act as a loyal guardian dog of the Euro-technocracy in the Council.
Other passages, then, do not agree with me at all.
First of all, I do not see how it is possible to propose today as a priority the acceleration of the EU's enlargement process towards the Balkan countries.
There are other problems to be addressed immediately before worrying about how to integrate countries in Europe affected by corruption and crime.
And then Turkey, the Danish government is pushing hard for Turkey's accession.
Fortunately, Turkey is far from reaching the EU's entry criteria.

But the real paradox is that, at a time when the euro is at risk of collapse, it should be the Danish Presidency to save it, the country, Denmark, out of the euro area, because the euro, obviously, has never been trusted.
The increase in violations of intellectual property rights has been recorded in recent years in the European Union.
These years risk compromising the strategy on intellectual property rights in the single market launched by the Commission in May 2011.

tasks relating to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, established in 2009, to the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market.

This is in order to provide the Observatory itself with human and financial resources to take action against infringements of intellectual property and awareness-raising campaigns to raise consumer awareness of the risks associated with the purchase of counterfeit products.

The vote in favour expressed in the report is thus a moment of great importance in the fight against the trade in counterfeit goods and in defence of innovation, growth and competitiveness of SMEs, as well as employment and the safety of European citizens.
Mr President, intellectual property may appear contradictory within its definition, but vice versa, it has great moments of coherence.

I voted in favour of this proposal because its purpose, namely to entrust the European Union's registration office with the design and design of some tasks related to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, is necessary and indispensable in order to combat violations of intellectual property rights.

The main objectives are to raise awareness in the public and private sectors of the impact of counterfeiting and piracy and to inform consumers of the dangers associated with the purchase of counterfeit products.
On the basis of the 33 compromise amendments, the agreement was reached at first reading on 19 December.
The amendments provide that the title of the regulation and the name of the Office are not amended in the sense of the European Observatory.

All this will make a synthesis moment even more democratic and participatory, like the one we are about to celebrate with today's vote.
Mr President, Mr President, the report by Mr Lehner is part of that framework of actions aimed at improving services for citizens and businesses within the European Union.

The interconnection of central and commercial registers is in fact a great tool for making communication and the retrieval of information by citizens and businesses more accessible and, above all, faster.
Therefore, Mr President, I express my vote in favour.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, whenever the situation seems to be improving, there are new declines in rating agencies, which are shaking the course of international markets.
Many European companies are in crisis and the number of people, especially the youngest, in the chronic search for employment is increasing on the employment front.
While austerity plans and the defence of the euro are necessary measures, deep labour market reforms aimed at reviving the European economy are even more necessary at national level.
Only by reviving competitiveness will the European Union give new confidence to investors and promote the growth of new jobs.
Mr President, I do not deny that the rights of homosexuals must be protected, which I deny, and in Italy, there are no families without children.

They will never exist simply because the family to be protected, the one that the European Parliament should also protect, is the traditional family, the one formed by a woman, a man and his children.
Everything here seems to me to be quite elementary.
This is the reality in Italy and the other 22 countries.

Mr President, first of all I would like to join in the affectionate greeting of Mr Lechner and also in the appreciation of his work, which has been carried out with competence, tenacity and determination.

It was a job of Certosino, every now and then this proposal for a regulation got stuck and he withdrew it, he started dealing with the Council, with the Commission, with the Legal Affairs Committee, I think I can be proud of that.
I see that there is unanimous consensus on it.

Coming to this regulation of ours, I am also convinced that it is an important thing, perhaps it is not in the newspapers, perhaps it is not considered high policy, but the construction of the European Union also passes.
It is a work of satisfaction of the interests of the citizens in their daily lives and, above all, of those millions and millions who, living on horseback in different States, are suffering.
They face difficult, boring practices and sometimes touch the sensitivity in the heart of a family that politics generally finds difficult to deal with.
The European Union must be proud to base its attention on this kind of thing.

The solutions that have been proposed are smart and new solutions, for example, the faculty has been given to those who have to make a will to choose between the usual residence or the state of origin.
This makes a decision more flexible, given that there are such deep, really very deep differences between one State and another that could constantly make the issue of succession difficult.
However, we have also been given certainty in the law, because once the legal solution or habitual residence or country of origin has been chosen, it is not possible to apply for asylum.

It determines a limitation of the discretion of judges and also a limitation of the conflicts that may arise and therefore a more peaceful way of proceeding in this field and therefore there is more freedom and more certainty.

And then the certificate of succession, which we believe is a matter of little importance, creates the conditions for the heir to have a greater degree of flexibility and certainty in the face of all the possible difficulties that might arise.
It is a fact that positively characterizes this law.

And then it is true, this law is not perfect, there are problems concerning the executor of the will, the feasibility of direct inheritance and so on, but I do not want to say just one more word of a political nature.
We hope that the Council will approve this text, we hope that it will become a regulation, but we must not put a tombstone on this text, because we cannot even stand by the text.
We see England in a different position from Britain, because Europe cannot do without Britain, and so we should proceed to overcome these difficulties later.
Thank you, sir.
Mr President, the European Union has produced a huge amount of laws and regulations to build European law and has created the European area, called the Stockholm Plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use that citizens make of it, which is numerically and percentage-wise very low.
On the other hand, national judges, the national lawyers of individual states, have grown up within the law of their own country and have a prevalent training in this field.
In this sense, while we think that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mind and who is intrigued by the knowledge of European law.

That is why, before we talk about training, we must talk about a great communication to citizens and to legal practitioners, so that they become the bearers of this great novelty and increase their ability to want to use the benefits of this right.

But above all, it is a movement from below that must be created in training in the service. You cannot give lessons to schoolchildren in the judicial training of adults and highly qualified professionals.

We must stimulate curiosity in dealing with our own cases, in connecting with other colleagues and in finding solutions, since today common law and civil law converge, they are no longer as distant as they used to be within the legal culture.

This is the real point in our proposals and I am glad that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects in our conviction we are asking for a reversal of the trend bottom up more legal studies than judicial training.
There is an example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra, which is very interesting, a network of officials in every court who radiate this knowledge and urge the magistrates in this.
That is the essence of our project and we hope that it will have the full support of the Commission.

Mr President, first of all I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the work done by Mr Giegold on this own-initiative report and I would also like to recall that we share an active presence with him and others in this Parliament's Social Economy Intergroup.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the fundamental characteristics of the European integration project, so not just one of the many policies, but a policy that characterizes our project.

And of these times, with the attacks also linked to the needs of cuts in public spending, etc., we still defend this priority convincingly, we know that it can be an updated or modified social model, but we also believe that it should be maintained, defended and reiterated as a priority.

So I think that in this same vision we must also value the economic actors who do business, who produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, and who play a very special role in the so-called European social economy.

They reiterate that you can produce, you can do good things, you can be efficient, even if you do not have profit as a goal, but for example you have employment, welfare, the valorization of work and the contribution to the life of the local community.

That is why it is important, and I conclude, Mr President, that Europe should make available the useful instruments for an active policy and that a good statute - not the one that is now inapplicable, but a good statute for cooperatives - can be a way of helping this very important sector.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and fairer economic dimension.
It is clear that the role of cooperative societies is becoming crucial at a time when we are going through one of the most serious economic and social crises since the post-war period.
There has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy, which has resulted in an increase in employment, more skilled work and a more balanced redistribution of wealth.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there is a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must be done by helping and not by creating bureaucratic obstacles.
That is why I voted in favour of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will work actively to solve the problems mentioned.
Mr President, the safety of millions of Europeans unemployed is not dependent on the generous assistance offered by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.
In many cases they are unemployed to give up this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The FTA is not a solution and does not address the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy which is managed dangerously and too lightly by the Commission.

In order to combat the scourge of structural unemployment, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose real competition is the main cause of the bankruptcy of our companies.
As long as Europe does not stop promoting economic self-determination, defending a short-sighted position on global trade flows, our companies will continue to fail.
The fund can only be a temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and security.
I think it is a great achievement for the European Parliament today, because what he wrote on 15 July was a great achievement for the European Parliament.
President Buzek, saying that we must set up an anti-mafia committee, I remember that there were so many colleagues from different countries who said that the mafia is a problem in Sicily and Italy.

Today, having been recognised by my colleagues from the north of Europe as a problem of organised crime in Europe and having the will to fight it all together, I think it is a great and important fact and I want to say thank you, Mr President, thank you to the whole Parliament.

I would also like to emphasize first of all our solidarity with the families of the victims of the serious clashes that took place on 16 December in Zanzibar, as well as our concern about the subsequent development of events.

The one that was originally essentially a trade union warning has degenerated into the most serious incidents in which 17 people lost their lives and in the days following the incidents in the arrests of journalists and opposition representatives.

It is in the interest of all, and as Kazakhstan has also demonstrated in the first person, to shed full light on the events, and I hope that today's event will be seen only as a positive opportunity for our Parliament to deepen what has happened so far.

I would like to reiterate our call for an inquiry that assures the international community that the responsibility for the events in Zanzibar will be clarified and those responsible prosecuted with the utmost respect for the principles of legality and protection of human rights.

The delegation, with the honour of chairing, had the opportunity, during some of its meetings, to listen to the explanations provided by the Kazakh authorities and also by some NGOs very active in observing events in this country.
The willingness of the Kazakh authorities to provide explanations and the promises of further clarifications are certainly positive elements, which must of course be appreciated by all of us.

That is why I would also like to emphasize the need to maintain a certain balance, a balance which I would have liked to find highlighted also in the text of the resolution which we will have to vote on tomorrow and which, in my view, is a good one.
In my view, it might have been appropriate to postpone the conclusion of the official investigations, which would have been useful to accompany with an official mission of international bodies.

The undeniable need to clarify what has happened and to call for greater and greater efforts by Kazakhstan to improve progress on the path to democracy must also be constantly accompanied by a renewed commitment and an open and constructive dialogue with this country.

Madam President, I voted in favour of this proposal because it aims to update the 2004 regulations in order to adapt to the changes in national legislation in the Member States on social security and to keep pace with the changes in social reality affecting the coordination of the security systems themselves.

This proposal also includes proposals from the Administrative Committee for the Coordination of Security Systems, whose purpose is to improve, modernise and acquire in accordance with Article 72 (f) of the previous Regulation.

The amendments contained in this proposal are intended to ensure legal certainty for interested parties and also to ensure appropriate coordination at European Union level of the national social security system.

It also reflects the legislative changes that have taken place at national level and it was necessary to approve it because it takes account of recent developments in cross-border mobility that affect the coordination of social security systems.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the credibility of the European Union at international level and the effectiveness of its human rights policies certainly go through condemning violations, abuses and injustices.

It is also important to avoid discrimination based on religion or belief, to avoid discrimination based on race, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, disability, age, sexual orientation and sexual orientation.

It is a common good, because it provides 15 of the proteins to over 3 billion people and the lives of over 500 million depend on fishing and aquaculture.

The debate on the reform of the common fisheries policy has, from today, one more reason to support actions that take European policy out of the narrow angle on the ways of drawing on resources and on a policy of rules all directed at the interior.

On the contrary, it suggests a strategy on the sea as a privileged place to increase its reproductive capacity, both in inland waters and through innovative methods of fishing agreements with third countries.

The third amendment to the regulation, 1 January
The proposal for a directive presented by the European Commission in a short time contains provisions aimed at creating a European instrument for risk sharing.

The aim is, in fact, to deal with the difficulties encountered by some Member States in collecting the private funding needed for the implementation of investment projects which can only be partly financed by the use of public funds.

Although the road to recovery from the economic crisis is still long, I consider the work done to reach a compromise text which has set a maximum for the funds to be allocated to the financial instrument and better defined as risk-sharing instruments to be fruitful.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the economic crisis, technological development and demographic changes have changed society and the labour market in Europe in recent years.

To meet future skills requirements, many people will have to complete higher education, many workers will have to continuously update their skills and knowledge, even though they are already employed.

That is why I voted in favour of Mr Tokes' text, which aims to modernise higher education systems to achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy and to promote social, cultural and economic development within the Union.
Mr President, I shall not go into too much detail, because in the short term I would just like to mention a few things.

I believe that this seventh programme of action for the environment can certainly prove to be a useful instrument, provided that it is based on a vision of the future which takes account of the need to maintain a solid European industrial base, which is essential to maintain a level of decent and acceptable employment.
There are some things that concern me.
I believe that it is an absolute priority that this programme ensures the most effective implementation of existing regulation before it is even set up.

I am deeply convinced that, in order to meet today's environmental challenges, we must rely on future environmental policies based on solid evidence, on the most up-to-date scientific knowledge, and on the most up-to-date scientific knowledge.

I am concerned about Article 24, which speaks of ecological footprint as an absolute indicator, it represents an indicator and an empirical model of reality, not reality itself, we must keep this in mind.

This has many limits, it tells us how much we affect the environment, but it does not absolutely estimate, for example, the quality of the environment, so my concerns remain and I invite everyone to take them into account.
When we talk about good examples for citizens, we have to talk about the internal market and the possibility of creating jobs and growth.
