We are utopian.

No, because a European internal market requires that tariffs be similar between domestic and non-domestic, there is no difference if we are talking about the single market, and above all because there is no technical justification for the increase in costs.
I remember when in 2007 we started talking about voice roaming, the first roaming of the third one we are.
There was a certain incredulity and also a certain difficulty, not from the Commission, but from its predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

The difficulties were very widespread, they came from those who said that the position of a real market does not provide for tariff regulation, they are political prices, they belong to an old conception of the left, etc. There were those who said that it does not work and so on, it brakes the market, but in the end we did it.
The fact that there were no technical justifications for the increase in costs led to a very difficult situation.
So the world is traveling, things are becoming more and more possible, so I think it's possible to have an even more courageous result.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
Perhaps, among the many benefits, this extra EU enlargement makes us understand that the possibility of using it without a real fear of costs also helps democracy.
In Europe, there are more than 120 million broadband users, at least 70 million citizens who use their mobile device to connect to the Internet, work, study or simply get information.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene in favour of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international telephone, voice, data and SMS traffic.
A positive decision because the price reduction programme will lead to an average fall in tariffs of 35 in the next three years.

But this is not enough, at a time as difficult as the present, both under the economic profile and under the employment profile, communication, new technologies and innovation are a primary good that Europe must defend with more courage.
Each European citizen must be able to move freely between Member States, using the telephone tariff set by his national operator.

If we really want to give a concrete answer to the citizens, we create a kind of Schengen of telecommunications that no longer imposes different tariffs on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was part of the European Parliament delegation which visited Sicily last November.
Our head of delegation, Cecilia Wistrom, wrote a letter to the Italian Minister of the Interior, the Chancellor, and she had a response that gave us quite clear answers.

I would like to recall above all the fact that after that visit to Italy the government has changed and the approach to the situation has also changed, but so has the situation itself in the countries from which the migration flow originated.
However, this must not deprive us of the need for a careful analysis of what has happened and also of the current situation.

The most relevant fact that is still relevant today is the status of Lampedusa as a non-safe port, the closure of the first aid and reception centre in Contrada Embria, following the fire in the port of Lampedusa.
The first was in September 2011, which damaged it but only partially, that is, a dormitory destroyed, one damaged on seven buildings of the structure and then the de facto abolition of the project.

Now it is worth considering that in the Mediterranean the only unsafe port was that of Tripoli in the days of Gaddafi, and this analogy does not seem flattering to me, since the migration flows, although considerably reduced in number, also for seasonal reasons, are increasing.

It is important that a first aid and reception operation works and works in Lampedusa, which is the first port of call for those arriving from the other side after not necessarily easy or risk-free journeys, as the Somali shipwrecked who arrived in Lampedusa know well.

In April of this year, after seeing 10 people die on the boat they were traveling on, or the 20 who were transferred from Linosa because there was no room in other reception centers, or the 18 who still live in Linosa in the stadium's locker rooms.

The tourist residence of Cala Creta, where they are staying today, is certainly not a CIE or a cara, and especially in the meantime, both the health system and the possibility of applying for asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything is entrusted to the good will and good heart of the police officers of the guard or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration is the function that the Centre itself had assumed in the recent past.

To have allowed thousands and thousands of people to accumulate against all legal and ethical norms in a place that, for the capacity and function to which it was destined, could only accommodate a few hundred.

To have allowed a territory of a few square kilometres, already difficult for the position and logistical difficulties, to be forced to accommodate a number of people greater than its own inhabitants, must make the necessary adjustments.
We must reflect on the responsibilities for a situation of extreme tension.
I think it's a good idea to do it in the fire itself.
I believe that Mr Rinaldi's excellent report has been a success in the House.
I absolutely share the flattering judgment on the report.
Nevertheless, I would like to raise a small question: our Europe, compared to this new world which seeks to find democracy and different economic conditions, is a Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is precisely to the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to pay particular attention, both in terms of the environmental aspects and in terms of the economic transactions that take place in the Mediterranean.
They'll put it in a fishing spot.
We are building a new fisheries policy in Europe which will set very rigid rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules.
So why not use forms of fisheries agreements to support these countries so that they apply the same rules as those in Europe?

But this would be good for European fisheries, it would be good for the sea, for the conservation of the environment, to ensure that this gap is less and less broken, but that it is more and more a homogeneous place on which to build the future of Europe and this new world.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament has become a full institutional subject in the field of security policies and therefore has the right to participate actively and decisively in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the Union's security model.

Mrs Borsellino's report identifies the five key areas for which concrete action has been proposed and calls for greater judicial and police cooperation between Member States in the fight against organised crime and terrorism.
I think it is particularly important to take into account the development of prevention policies, which are a fundamental instrument for ensuring a space of freedom, security and European justice.
Mr President, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations for the development of criminal law integrated into Community law have been laid.

While stressing the importance of mutual recognition, harmonization, protection rules and the principle of presumption of innocence, it is good to emphasize how the law must be extremely clear and easily understandable in order to make it clear to everyone which action constitutes a crime.
This applies in particular to directives which must be reciprocal to national law.
Any lack of clarity could in fact lead to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close cooperation between the European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can ensure a coherent and high-quality European strategy in the field of criminal law.

Mr President, the European Union guarantees the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising and abusive contractual clauses, but there is no such thing as unfair competition.
There is no doubt that those consumers who are more vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health problems or simply lack of proper information should be more carefully protected.
I therefore voted in favour of Mrs Peres' text because I agree that the creation of a consumer law strategy
The European Union must help the so-called most vulnerable not only to be socially included, but also to ensure a safer, fairer and more competitive single market.
Mr President, Mr Perez's report, on which we voted in favour, stresses the need to take account of the preparation of a report by the European Parliament.

A new strategy is aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in view of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop in this respect.
Consumer vulnerability arises from different causes and can potentially affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide for the protection of this category alongside that of the general consumer and to provide for a targeted strategy to this end, taking into account the complex nature of the problem.

On the one hand, it prohibits the formulation of static and rigid definitions and is unable to take into account all the facts of the case and the various possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other hand, it prohibits the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to define specific and targeted protection measures.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the management of red tuna fishing has a long and rather complex history since the 1990s and is probably the most strictly disciplined in the European Union today.
Despite the large investments in control, which have led to greater compliance with the rules, there are still some confusion about the problem of overfishing.
I therefore expressed my support for the Romeva i Rueda report, which proposes a reduction in the admissible rate of catch, greater control and a strengthening of measures to reduce capacity.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the relations between the European Union and China clearly show imbalances at the trade level.
It is therefore the duty of the European institutions to make an effort to help European companies to emerge from the crisis and to achieve fairer access to international markets.
I have therefore expressed my support for this report, sharing in particular, among the issues raised by the rapporteur, the application of the principle of reciprocity to trade.
relations between the European Union and China to allow fair competition on international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Ladies and gentlemen, the road ahead is still long, but today's vote can be an important step towards finally introducing and applying a financial transaction tax.
I understand the caution, the caution, the need for graduality expressed by Commissioner emeta and the technical problems which Minister Vestager rightly mentioned.

But that is precisely why I hope that Parliament will express a clear political will, with a large majority, to give impetus and impetus to the necessary initiatives to tackle the problems that are still open, especially at Council level.
We all want to assess carefully the impact of this tax, but it is not right to stir up unjustified fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic of the exemption proposal.
If you are careful to reduce the impact of the tax, then it is important to have the widest possible tax base, with a low levy, and not to try to extend exemptions indefinitely.
I would remind those who are concerned about the reflections on small investors of the progressive nature of the tax, which affects more those who carry out more operations and more transactions.
It is clear that the competent authorities will have to be vigilant in any case so that they do not try to impose any possible costs on customers and end-users.
I therefore hope that Parliament will vote by a large majority in favour of this tax.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since 1990, through the macro-financial assistance instrument, the European Union has been granting economic aid in the form of subsidies, loans or a combination of both to countries in difficulty with the balance of payments in the short term.
The rather long timing, coupled with the difficulties highlighted by the decision-making criteria used so far, have made it necessary to make some changes to the regulation.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to make evaluation criteria faster and more effective and to agree on clearer rules and conditions for the granting of macro-financial assistance.
Mr President, there are some 100 million European citizens engaged in various voluntary activities.

From major sporting events to cultural events, the role of volunteers is crucial and the work of those who need to provide help and solidarity in the event of serious natural or environmental disasters should not be overlooked.
Volunteering is one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I hope that a high-quality national and cross-border volunteering will be developed and that the obstacles that currently exist will be removed.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from the communications sector to finance, transport, energy, culture and health, the role of technology is becoming increasingly important.
The increasing use of the Internet and digital media makes the issue of computer security one of the priorities of the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can in fact only promote economic and social development if the rules in force guarantee the security of users with regard to data retention and intellectual property rights.

For this reason, only full international cooperation involving Member States, institutions and industries in the sector can give rise to a solid system capable of introducing effective measures to ensure computer security.
Madam President, thank you, Commissioner, you have said some very important and very understandable things.
I think it is really, as he said, shocking that we have lived, each in our own country, with the numbers and figures we heard earlier from Mrs Oconia.
But it is equally clear that this scandal has really highlighted the need for a careful assessment of the European legislation currently in force on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the shortcomings we have spoken about so far in this House, which the Commissioner has so well represented, and I would therefore not like to dwell on the short time at my disposal in this respect.
I think it is good to put in place everything necessary so that we can have the best to offer our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so much, could also be a stepping stone to take another step forward, and I agree with what my colleague said earlier.

The communication that is made to patients is really scarce, the positive aspect is always emphasized, it is said that there is a kind of eternal youth, promised beauty, there are no prosthetics that are absolutely risk-free.

I believe that this awareness, especially when it comes to pure aesthetic surgery, should really be communicated to people, to girls, because we know that there are very young people who are approaching this type of intervention.
So I see that you are absent with conviction and so I recommend that we really work, the times are tight, we should have done it yesterday.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Council regulation on the multiannual plan for the stock of rhino was adopted before the Treaty came into force and therefore a alignment was necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the Treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, since the solution adopted in this case could affect the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
That is why I often vote in favour.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, from Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, there are many environmental disasters that have struck Europe in recent years and endangered the health of European citizens.

Mr Ader's text concerns the revision of the Seveso II Directive, which aims to contain the effects of those incidents connected with large quantities of dangerous and highly polluting substances dispersed in the environment.

The revised rules, which will come into force from June 2015, are aimed at protecting the environment and, above all, limiting the tragic consequences for the health of citizens, and I therefore voted in favour.
Mr President, I too thank Mr Stevenson for the excellent work and approach he has given to this report, which deals mainly with the two main issues.

This is not just a plan for the management of harbours, it is essentially about guaranteeing a future for fishermen for some waters and planning in the sea to ensure that this, in a multiannual manner, has its protections.
But the key point of this report is and remains the question of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council must accept the approach given by the Treaty of Lisbon and I also think that the time has come for Parliament, in some way, to speak with a voice perhaps more authoritative than that of the Council.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is prepared to accept the amendments tabled by the Committee on Fisheries and Aquaculture and the amendments tabled by the Committee on Fisheries and Aquaculture.
We claim the right that there should really be ordinary procedure in these matters.

I am well aware that the issue also involves, in addition to many other fisheries sectors, which will, among other things, worsen compared to the ongoing reform, but it concerns issues relating to agriculture and other issues.
The essential step is to respect Parliament's will.
The drafting of this report has not taken any account of the direct interests of the car transport companies.
In Italy, 91% of freight is transported by rubber.
Their rights will be ignored if this report is adopted in its present form.
In many committees in this Parliament we work every day to reduce the financial and administrative burden on our companies, but reports like this are futile.
We will do our best, because they will suffocate the companies themselves with new bureaucratic burdens, with devastating economic losses and with new forms of unfair competition.
It would have been little to obtain a balanced report which did not forget the right of survival of our companies in a very difficult economic period, but such a dialogue was not possible.

On the contrary, the report deliberately ignored even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 Working Time Directive, and even ignored the European Commission's documents, which recognised the dangers of practices such as retrofitting, which are instead proposed in this report.

The document we are voting on tomorrow, ladies and gentlemen, will ask you to forget the positive achievements that have been made in recent years and that European companies will once again have to pay for the expenses.

Just to say, Mr President, that ACTA was a very serious political mistake, let alone a legal one, it caused a reaction in the world of immense proportions and that is enough to say that it is a political mistake.
Why the Bense?
Because it created the suspicion that the access to the web was really being shut down, which is a great modern revolution.
And why is that?
Because he made the mistake of combining counterfeiting and piracy, which are two distinct phenomena.
The way to fight counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.
And then there is another mistake, which has cut Parliament out of an important activity that it has been carrying out for a long time, which is to create a new copyright, a new copyright.
So the point is that we have to work on copyright and put aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, and shut it down and exclude it, because it's an obstacle to our work.
Fortunately, after months and years of hesitation, the Commission has brought two important measures to Parliament's attention: orphan works and the next one, on copyright management companies.
So let's work on this by reflecting with the brain and not just with emotion, but without having ACTA between our feet.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, simply to add my voice to the applause that this report has received in the House in relation to the need to strengthen the capacity of the European Union to act.
We want to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce and produce in the light of our conception of an inclusive, socially and environmentally sustainable economy.

So I think that some of the indications here are very useful in this measure, others can be added and I think it is important to collect this indication, to work more and more because attractiveness is the key.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens and mutagens has been rejected by the Council.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter, and if he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about sensitive issues such as the authorisation of products and substances for use in biological productions, we are talking about protecting the health of European citizens.

It is important to meet consumer expectations as regards the quality of organic products circulating on European markets and it is also important to ensure that Community legislation is properly applied by the authorities, bodies and operators concerned.
That is why I voted in favour of the text.
Mr President, in spite of the first comments on the Council, the phase of reduction reading has now begun, and this is wrong, because important steps have been taken.
Think, for example, of the breakdown of the destructive links between banks and public debts, and of the weak employment level.

The spirit of revival and a renewed path of political unity seems to be re-emerging in the European institutions after so much slowness and sluggishness and a willingness to make real progress towards greater integration.
We have already seen strong unity between Parliament and the Commission on this.

I am not talking about winners and losers, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the previous diarchy, which was the denial, the very antithesis of the Community spirit.
There has been an initiative and an activism by several countries, not already to create new exclusionary axes, but to build a common and respectful consensus of all the Member States.
This is the path of the political objective of unity, without which any banking, fiscal and monetary union will be completely inadequate.

On 6 June, with the Council's decision to restore Member States' ability to re-establish border controls, a new Europe was born, a Europe courageous in fulfilling its citizens' desire to be part of the European Union.
It is finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, which is based on the defence of the rights, above all, of its peoples.

To President Schulz, even if he is not present, I say that this historic decision is not an interinstitutional incident, but respect for the will of the citizens and not for that Eurobureaucracy which for years has pretended not to understand what is really happening outside the Glass Palace.
No imaginary influx of illegal immigrants, Mr President Schulz, but an increase in illegal immigrants measured by Frontex of 35 in 2011.

I am only sorry that the scenes of political sterility consummated in this Chamber last plenary have robbed time of a more useful and constructive activity, to ask ourselves why it was not we but the Member States who defended the interests of our citizens.

If Parliament does not find the courage to go against the bonisme, the sterile obviousness on which it has been boasting for too long, it will continue to be gregarious and not a leader in the construction of the European project.
I want to draw the attention of this House to the fact that yesterday was a very important day.
It has been officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
The particle that gives mass to all the others is their existence, and this has happened on European soil.
Science gives life to our earth, civilization and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to become a capital of world science again.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents a utopia and wants to realize it, and it is for science and for this wonderful ambition of man that today a person is born.
A blind man who has no eyes can see with his hands or read a book with his ears, and a young South African boy who has no legs can run in the Olympics in a speed competition.
Well, Europe must be the home of science, and this great event, which will open new frontiers to knowledge, must be supported to the end by Europe.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, too often within the European Union victims of crime do not report because of fear or lack of confidence in the institutions.
The text voted today tends to strengthen the rights of victims of crime and to guarantee them the same level of protection, assistance and access to justice in criminal proceedings.
In all the countries of the Union, special attention should be paid to those victims who are at high risk of further prejudice or intimidation in the course of criminal proceedings.

It is therefore of particular importance to recognise the status of victim, not only for those who have suffered prejudice as a result of a crime, but also for the family members and the person who died as a result of the crime.
On 11 September, the Catalan people peacefully demonstrated in Barcelona.
One million people have asked for Catalonia's independence from Spain.
On 15 October, British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to allow a referendum on Scotland's independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, in recent weeks, thousands of people have signed to hold a referendum on independence from Veneto and Italy.
Yesterday, in Veneto, in Lombardy and in all the regions of the North, hundreds of thousands of people signed up to have more autonomy than Rome.
But also in Flanders, in the Basque Country, citizens are calling loudly for autonomy and independence from the national states.
What does President Schulz say?
It requires a courageous commitment to say clearly no to all separatist tendencies.
His vice-president, Vidal Quadras, even worse, has even called for the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements are a very serious act, contrary to the principles of that democracy which we preach here and which we must defend.
I tell them that it will be the peoples who will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats in Brussels.
The road is already paved.
The policy of austerity adopted to get out of the economic crisis has not produced the hoped-for results.
As the report by Mr La Via has pointed out, only by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget with a higher level of investment will we be able to achieve this.
In order to support growth and employment, it will be possible to rebalance the economies of the Member States, improving the situation of European citizens.
That is why I voted in favour.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With Member States committed to making tax adjustments to their national budgets to replenish public finances, the European Union is seen in some cases as an entity that adds to the financial burden on taxpayers.

Therefore, in order to really get out of the crisis and ensure a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investment in the fields of training and development.
This is the programming document of an institution, from the budget you understand what it is, what it does and, above all, what it wants to do in the future.

We are faced with a crucial choice between a survival budget, a budget of drag, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investment for employment, for innovation and for young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

Everyone should understand that, as Mr Kalfin has very clearly said, Europe can do today what the States can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories where social cohesion is affirmed or the lives of the citizens we have spoken of are destroyed.
The great European choices today risk being stifled by the rationalist disputes within the Council, but not only between beneficiary countries, payers and paying countries.

We say it's a false problem because it's easy to show with numbers, not words, what's happened in the past that the contributing countries, sometimes more than others, take advantage of the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is working these days to put figures alongside the various headlines.

The war of positions has begun, statements, positions of some States which consider the budget to be the tail of any spending voice which can be cut short without remorse, perhaps even useful to foster an anti-European sentiment easy to incite in times of economic crisis.
It is a wrong position which does not help the integration we are trying to make in other fields.
Ladies and gentlemen, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as we have said many times.
We have adopted a stability pact, which should also have been for development, but we have stabilised so much that we are in recession.
Let us at least seize the opportunity of this budget, of this multiannual framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Lack of information and awareness of one's rights, to which are added the obstacles of the lack of information and awareness of one's rights.

Linguistic problems and the lack of recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems faced by citizens of the Union when residing, studying or working in another country of the European Union.
Unfortunately, there is still a lack of visibility of the concept of citizenship of the Union and its concrete advantages.
That is why I expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is to strengthen the awareness of the rights connected with citizenship of the Union and to help citizens to exercise fully their right to move and reside freely in the territories of the Member States.
Madam President, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance and control of their effectiveness.
In fact, a fair balance must be struck between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at European level is nevertheless of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, especially in times of crisis, can stimulate investment in the economy.

In a context where the continuing decline in the responses to the Community budget is counteracted by the constant growth of its political ambitions, the Commission's proposals for a new budgetary framework are not sufficient.
The Brussels I Regulation has undoubtedly been one of the most effective acts of the European Union in the field of international trade.
It has laid the foundations for a European judicial area, promoted and promoted the certainty of the law among European citizens.
The dissemination of this regulation touches on fundamental issues for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules on the
on the competence of disputes with potential third-country nationals and agreements on the choice of the competent forum.
I am convinced that the adoption of the new regulation can ensure stronger consumer protection and greater certainty of the law within the internal market, and that is why I voted in favour.

Mr President, Commissioner, today Europe is called upon to take on a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most ardent supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for this role to be exercised.
Without a greater Europeanisation of national strategies, even under the guise of protecting employment, the current crisis will not be overcome and there will be no revival.
The car crisis is not just overcapacity, it's dramatic job losses.
But the crisis now seems structural and concerns the very fate of the car, of the product, as it is today.
We want to keep the automotive industry in Europe and we do not want to lose existing skills and know-how, professional skills.
We therefore call for a major renovation and relaunch project to be launched and done in a short time, because the costs are proportional to the times.
Restructuring cannot be the result of fragmented national decisions or individual enterprises.
We must at least try to coordinate and guide this painful process at Community level by bringing the stakeholders around the table with social dialogue.
It provides support to producers, trade unions and national governments, research, innovation, human capital training, retraining and the necessary funds.
I know it will be a difficult task, because the national interests of individual enterprises are not at stake.

But since the competitive conflict in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I think it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective Community impetus and guidance to face together the increasingly aggressive world market.
Madam President, the energy crisis has cost and is costing all employment, thousands of precarious but also stable and temporary workers, many of whom are in this sector.
The major steel groups are increasingly oriented towards the Far East or the American continent and pose a great question to us about the direction of our development model.
I think that Europe must recover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic products capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, and we will support it, Commissioner, if we are to stop the industrial decline.

I think we have to get out of a dualism which is not spoken of here tonight, but which is often heard in the discussions on this sector, a dualism between environmentalists and workers, which is wrong because it does not give us a perspective for the future.
An industry that sees steel as an integral part needs advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard different interests, different needs.

We therefore need a strong European design, which focuses on sustainability, which I do not think we should go back on as an added value, with which we want to compete in the world, by supporting investment, as has been said.

I have spoken on several occasions about new technologies, new processes, the requalification of plants for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, starting with energy resources and also the search for new and different materials.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we have recalled in this House, next December the United Nations Agency for Communication and Information Technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The aim is to renegotiate international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget, and I am pleased with the words of Commissioner Tajani, the work that has been done so far, which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed.

We have a supranational structure like ITU, of which we know that hundreds of states around the world are part, many of which are known for a problem related to democracy, transparency and freedom of expression.
So it is not wrong to believe that the pillars of the Internet, namely freedom, participation, openness and innovation, are in danger.
So I think it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet, the role that the Internet in particular can play in reviving economic growth, but not only in ensuring opportunities for everyone.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards the objective of bringing Europe together in Dubai and speaking with one voice.

There are many controversial proposals on the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, in particular those that seek to change internet governance, which call into question the neutrality of the network with negative consequences for consumers.
The freedom of the Internet, or more precisely the freedom of expression and data protection, is therefore at stake.
What some states have proposed would allow a government to get its nose into not only the communications of its citizens, but even the data that passes through its networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression and censorship is extremely short and therefore I believe it is contrary to the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have expressed my support for the text of the report and I particularly agree with the rapporteur in emphasising the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of the law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union to improve and coordinate training in the field of jurisdiction for judicial and administrative authorities and for legal professionals.
All sectoral initiatives should also be intensified in order to fully realize the concept of a Union based on the rule of law.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years the extraction of so-called unconventional hydrocarbons, including shale gas and shale oil, has led to an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
In order to cope with this situation and to be less dependent on hydrocarbon imports, Europe will therefore have to rely on its own possible gas and shale reserves.
In this respect, some Member States have already authorised the search for shale gas and are preparing for the extraction phase if the discovery so permits.
In such a context, it becomes necessary to monitor the rules on the extraction of shale gas within the Union's borders, so that the effects of its extraction are reduced.
The extraction of minerals, which are undoubtedly economically viable, does not create environmental problems for the possible release of harmful substances into the atmosphere's aquifers.
Mr President, I believe that today's debate should be an opportunity to speak objectively about Kazakhstan and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country for the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is undoubtedly an important economic and commercial part of the European Union.
This is a country which has already begun a process of economic reforms and also a democratic process, but which still has a lot of work to do to bring these processes to a complete completion.
However, it is a country which, with this objective, persists in proving itself ready for new and stronger reforms, and I believe that this is the task of the European Union itself to accompany them.

That is why I am sure that the signing of this strengthened agreement will allow steps forward, because its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and ensure constant assistance from the European Union.

I am also convinced, and I think this should have been further emphasised in the report we are voting on tomorrow, that improving progress on the road to democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed and mutual commitment, open and constructive.

Our objective must not be to put ourselves in negative terms with these and other countries in the face of the lack of immediate change, but to support their efforts to achieve the objective of respect for human rights principles.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteurs of the reports we are voting on tomorrow for just a small passage on the push and I join in what I have heard this evening as a unanimous voice from all the colleagues.
But I wanted to dwell on the Cartigera report, on the Ferrera report, which I welcome and with which I compliment myself.

I wanted to say one thing: with the common fisheries policy in place, the only thing that has been done is to increase the distance between the institutions that regulate fisheries and their real actors, i.e. fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now, in Europe, the lack of a true definition of artisanal fishing has penalized those who have always understood fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas and their cuisine.

The Commission's line was to uniformise all fishing in Europe under the large industrial fishery, following only market logic and not listening to the reasons of the thousands of fishermen who, for a couple of years, have been trying to do so.

For decades they have operated according to rules that are consistent with the conservation of the ecosystem, on which I can only agree, but which have never preserved the working activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This own-initiative report is a strong signal to the Commission that it can be translated into practical actions in favour of the fisheries microeconomy.
The report highlights a number of advantages of allocating a minimum amount to small-scale fishing under the European Fund.

We will have to encourage projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole and, moreover, it will have to be essential, Commissioner, to encourage young people to access the European Union.

We have spoken about this sector several times in committee, because otherwise not only will fishing probably die because of the plain of the seas and the fish, but it will probably die because young people are no longer getting closer to this sector.
This report is an opportunity to introduce training and incentive measures for young people who want to get closer to the sector.
Madam President, like many colleagues today, I ask the Council, which has made this proposal, but what do you want to do, ladies and gentlemen of Europe?
Do you want to minimize it, freeze it in the future?
But it is the same Europe that then wants to be relaunched with the Van Rompuy document on integration.
But with what coherence, I ask you, does Varro Poirier lead these two files?

What coherence can citizens find between the decisions of July, employment and growth, the loud calls for hope, for the future of the European Union, which we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall, in the name of realism, into a perspective of minimal survival?
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to transform into concrete acts and active policies the great reforms so much called for by the cohesion and the CAP?
These are sincere questions and we would like a clear, honest answer, because there are signs of institutional schizophrenia here that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
Parliament wants consistency, it wants credibility.
The first criticism is that at the budgetary level we are not ourselves, other than growth and investment, we are in the 2008 budget.
It is true that the role of the budget is recognised here as an irreplaceable driver of growth in some sectors, in addition to national budgets.

But both growth and innovation, it is clear, must not be at the expense of other sectors which are also part of growth and jobs, such as cohesion policy and also, ladies and gentlemen, agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and the protection of the territory.

The European Union's main area of activity is growth and jobs, culture, training, transnational networks, the CEF and also solidarity and international development, human rights in the world and our contribution to the Millennium Development Goal.

But unfortunately, in front of us is the usual spectacle of the Council, no vision, no guidance, a barrage of national interests, opposed and competing with each other, an inextricable hatred of vetoes, expectations and general discontent.
And Europe, unfortunately, is the great absentee.

Mr President, spinning is an unacceptable practice from an environmental point of view, as it threatens the sustainability of some species of sharks, which, from this point of view, are in danger of extinction.
This is a social and economic matter, since it implies the waste of a foodstuff of commercial value, as well as from an ethical point of view, since it shows a total lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been prohibited in the waters and for the European fleet since 2003, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the derogation from the ban on the export of shark fins to Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further ensuring that sharks are protected as they need to be, will enable the European Union to contribute actively to the ongoing global effort to eradicate the cruel practice of sharks' fins cutting in other parts of the world.
